name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 8 February 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As President of the European Parliament, as a citizen, as a journalist, I express my deepest indignation and my firm condemnation for the killing of Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak and his partner Martina Kušnírová, which took place near Bratislava. It is a new, unacceptable attack on press freedom, which is a founding value of our democracy. This murder comes within months of the tragic murder of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia. Ján Kuciak exercised his profession with passion and courage. Throughout his brief but promising career, he was conducting inquests into cases of suspicious funding and tax evasion. He sought the truth with determination, without looking in anyone's face. Police stated that he almost certainly was killed to stop his inquests. On behalf of Parliament, I want to say strongly that we all have a duty to continue its battle for the truth. It is not permissible today for a journalist to be killed within the European Union because he is playing his profession. How can we condemn those who intimidate and imprison journalists everywhere in the world, if we fail to guarantee freedom of the press and the possibility to safely carry out their jobs to journalists Europeans? I am counting on the Slovak authorities to do everything possible to get to the truth, including calling for international cooperation between policies. On behalf of the European Parliament, I can assure that, as with Daphne Caruana Galizia, we will not stop voicing our voice, continuing to ensure that all the perpetrators are brought to justice. As it happened to remember Daphne Caruana Galizia, I ask you to join me in a minute's silence. (The House, standing, observes a minute's silence) Unfortunately the last week has been full of negative news. Boko Haram terrorist group attacked a school in the North again East of Nigeria, and as a result of this attack over one hundred girls disappeared. It is a kidnapping that brings to mind the dramatic memory of schoolgirls kidnapped in Chibok, in 2014. The European Parliament strongly condemns this attack and calls for the release of these girls. Every child should be guaranteed the right to go to school in a safe and free environment. President Buhari called it a national disaster, but I have no fear to call it a worldwide humanitarian disaster. This tragic event should prompt us to engage more concretely at the political, financial and military level with our African partners in the fight against terrorism. I must also inform you of an incident which saw our colleague Ska Keller in Bulgaria a few weeks ago. Mr Keller was the subject of a statement by Minister Simeonov calling for her to be expelled from the country because of her participation in a protest rally against the construction of infrastructure in Pirin national park in Bulgaria. Just informed of this, I immediately intervened at the Bulgarian government and received assurance that Simeonov's statements do not represent the government's position. The incident thus resolved. I would like to reiterate that the freedom to express their opinion is a fundamental right for any citizen of the European Union, particularly those who, like Mr Keller, are elected by the people and represents the people who represent citizens. This freedom is the foundation of our democracy and entails the right to differ, to demonstrate and also to protest. I thank the Bulgarian Government for immediately distancing itself from these statements and I hope that such episodes will not happen again in the future.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Mr President, I very much appreciate the comments you have just made. I simply regret that this freedom of expression is not respected within Parliament itself. I deplore, in particular, that the Committee on Legal Affairs responsible for examining these issues systematically lifts the parliamentary immunity of minority members when it comes to the expression of their dissenting opinion, which was not the case when I entered this institution where it was the rule that political opinion should be exempted from prosecution, as long as it was pursued by political opponents and expressed by the parliamentarian. Today we are experiencing a very different situation where, in the very compound of this European Parliament, moreover, Members are punished, not because of the disruption they bring to the work of the Institution, but because of what they have made, so questionable as they may be, which seems to me to be quite contrary to the the very essence of parliamentary life. Thank you for hearing me, Mr. President.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, I thank you for bringing back the story of Boko Haram's girls to this House. I wanted to make another appeal to this Parliament: to fight terror. We must do this by investing more in education and above all in education. This Parliament has committed so much to the fight against Boko Haram, against the kidnapping of girls. I insist that this appeal does not remain in a vacuum. We invest against terror, with more education and education.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Parliament has always made its voice loud and loud to defend Cyprus's independence and to enforce the right at any time, even to a candidate country such as Turkey. I personally spoke and called the President of the Republic of Cyprus to express my sympathy to him.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, due to the situation in Venezuela about eight thousand citizens of European origin have returned to an outermost region of Europe, the Autonomous Region of Madeira. I would like to know, and I would like to take advantage of being here, Commissioner, what support and measures the Commission has available to help this region, which is so small and which receives so many migrants and which, since yesterday, has been hit by a major storm.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We will have to ask this from the European Commission, which is already engaged with an immigration strategy, and I believe that even in the next MFF there will be a commitment from all of us to address the issue of immigration — the legal, the illegal one, the refugees — and also a particular focus on Africa.

text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Thank you, Mr President. On the 20th of this month, we were able to read in the EU Observer that there is, and we have seen, a letter from Vice-President Katainen saying that on 25 October last year he met Mr Barroso, former President of the Commission, and that this meeting would have been about trade and defence. name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, on behalf of my Group, we wish to replace the debate on Thursday morning on the Nart report, on cutting the sources of income for jihadists, with a joint debate on jihadists, comprising the debate on the Nart report, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), and Council and Commission statements on jihadist brides returning to Europe. The reason for this is that Frontex last week estimated that there are a thousand jihadi brides planning on returning to our continent. These people have given up their right to their citizenships, be they French, German, British, Swedish – they have revoked their citizenship rights. They have rejected our way of life and Frontex says they are an evolving threat: they are terrorists pure and simple and they should not be allowed back onto this continent. If you don’t want more jihadist terrorism in your countries I suggest you agree to this urgent debate. As Gavin Williamson, the Conservative UK Defence Secretary, said, a dead terrorist can’t do any harm.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the President of Parliament on the humanitarian situation in Syria, in particular in Ghouta (2018/2602 (RSP)). I would remind Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure for this debate, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, seven years into the war in Syria, the suffering of the Syrian people unfortunately continues. Each new escalation brings a new humanitarian crisis and a new level of horror. Unfortunately it is now evident, as we have been saying for months and years, that the war is far from over, and a political solution is more urgent than ever.  The situation in Eastern Ghouta, where over 400 000 people are in dire need, is of extreme concern to me as Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid. I had hoped that the tragedy experienced in Aleppo last year was behind us, but unfortunately what is happening in Eastern Ghouta as we speak proves otherwise. The ongoing violence and human suffering are unacceptable. We have worked endlessly to stop the massacre and we went public in order to increase the pressure on the regime and its supporters. I issued a joint statement together with the High Representative on 19 February, and the High Representative also made a declaration on 23 February, on behalf of 20 of our Member States. We are equally concerned about the reports that chlorine gas is being used in Eastern Ghouta. Investigation in the field should definitely be supported. The EU sanctions regime has already been used to target perpetrators and can be mobilised again. The resolution adopted by the United Nations Security Council last Saturday is an essential step forward, but it is only a first step. As highlighted by the High Representative, it is now essential to implement a ceasefire to allow a genuine humanitarian pause for at least 30 consecutive days throughout Syria. For that reason, earlier this week the High Representative wrote to the three guarantors of the Astana process, Russia, Turkey and Iran. They have committed to creating four de—escalation zones and they have a special responsibility to work for an immediate ceasefire. This will enable safe, sustained delivery of humanitarian aid, as well as services and medical evacuations for the critically ill and the wounded, in accordance with applicable international law. We, the European Union, the principal humanitarian donor, are maintaining our commitment to delivering strictly on the basis of needs across the whole of Syria. In Eastern Ghouta we have been providing assistance across sectors including health, food and protection. We are in constant contact with our partners operating there on the ground. These include five UN agencies, the ICRC as always, and five international and local governmental organisations, which have pre-positioned the requisite emergency supplies to be delivered as soon as access is granted. I reiterated that it is a matter of the utmost urgency to allow access for our partners to deliver the long—awaited vital assistance. I am alarmed to witness the human suffering while assistance is waiting in warehouses. This is completely unacceptable.  The situation in Eastern Ghouta illustrates the plight of the three million vulnerable people trapped in besieged and hard-to-reach areas. I totally agree with you that it is time to act. I look forward to your support in continuing to call on the parties to the conflict to respect the UN resolution and allow humanitarian aid to be delivered.  (Applause)

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in South Damascus, in Eastern Ghouta, what the UN Secretary-General has described as 'hell on earth' is taking place. A regular army — the Syrian — with its allies — Russia — mercilessly bombs 400,000 desperate people. You, Mr. President, reminded us of the creepy images of the corpses of shrouded children who hit our conscience hard. As one Security Council diplomat said, every minute the international community has been waiting for Russia, many people have been killed. Russia has exercised its veto right in the Security Council eleven since the beginning of the Syrian conflict. That is why, Mr President, we must welcome the courage of Germany and France, Sweden and Kuwait, in calling for the adoption of this Security Council Resolution, which, unfortunately, as you reminded us, is not stopping horror. Now, the first priority, Mr President, is to alleviate the suffering of the population. As the High Representative said, the massacre must be put to an end: not for five hours, but definitely. International humanitarian law must be restored in Syria, respond, as the Commissioner said, with humanitarian aid and evacuate the wounded and sick from Ghouta. The European Union must continue to alleviate the effects of this terrible conflict, as it has done in Lebanon, as it has done in Egypt, as it has done in Iraq or as it has done in Jordan, and, at the same time, to favour international conferences, as was the case in London and also in Brussels. But, Mr President, the European Union must be involved and vigorously seek to mobilize all its efforts to find a stable and lasting peace in Syria and end this nightmare.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We cannot forget, Mr Salafranca, what the fundamentalist followers of the Islamic State are doing, who are killing a lot of people. That is why we must be tough on the Syrian and Russian armed forces, but we cannot forget what Islamic State terrorists are doing, for example, killing many Christians who are leaving Syria.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the tragic routine of more than seven years of war in Syria may give us the false idea that is there is not much we can do about it other than ignore it. There is a sense that the lives and the suffering of civilians dying under the bombs and chemical attacks of Assad, Russia and Iran-backed militias in Homs, Aleppo, Zabadani, Madaiya, Idlib and now Ghouta are just numbers – the casualties of a war without restraint.  The violation of international humanitarian law can be tolerated for some without any consequences for the future. You are so wrong. Our responsibility is greater than we are prepared to assume. All parties are guilty in the failure to prevent the worst bloodshed of the 21st century. The warning signals of a humanitarian catastrophe in Ghouta have been there for a long time, but the world has chosen to accept it with fatalism – tragic fatalism, I would say. I feel shame for those who are selling us this shameful apathy towards the Syrian massacre in the name of the so-called fight against terrorism. Shame on those who dare to close their eyes and hope that Russia will solve all their problems. You are deluded. The war in Syria might only be the beginning of war after war, which could be even worse. This is a place for wars. Do not underestimate the war and the traumas inflicted on all Syrian people and on the region because of the involvement of an increasing number of local and regional actors. What happens today will have repercussions in the long term. Refugees will not stop. The EU will continue to play its chronic inability to act. The UN Resolution asking for an immediate ceasefire continues to be ignored by Assad and his allies. A so-called ceasefire of only five hours has been implemented by Russia. This ceasefire was a poisoned gift that only served to allow Assad’s troops to advance on the ground. This move only side-lined the UN as a decision-maker and allowed Russia to impose its Pax Russica and further establish and strengthen its authority and role in the region. After Syria vetoed the UN Resolution on chemical weapons used in Syria, we have evidence today of the selling of arms, including chemical weapons, from North Korea to Syria. One question now hangs in the air: are we really unable today to make sure that at least the embargo on the selling of arms to Syria is respected? This is a devastating question mark for our Union and for humanity.  Finally, I will dare to look cautiously to the future. The only bridge to the future of the Syrian people is a ceasefire and a UN-led political solution, which includes UN monitoring and an enforcement mechanism. While sounding a bit naive, I hope that the butchers of Syria will be brought to international justice to answer for the war crimes and the crimes against humanity that they have committed.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, with the defeat of Isis, which is undoubtedly led by war criminals, the conflict in Syria has now finally reached the end game. As Turkey continues its own offensive against Afrin as a means to prevent any semblance of Kurdish governance along its borders, we now see the Assad regime seek to defeat the remaining rebel strongholds across Syria. The offensive in Eastern Ghouta on the outskirts of Damascus, home to some 400 000 civilians, is the latest target. It is those civilian, including women and children, who are being killed on a daily basis by bombings, that we must keep upmost in our minds at this time. It is they that will bear the brunt of this brutal seven—year tragic conflict.  I too welcomed the recent UN Security Council resolution imposing a ceasefire to allow for very short humanitarian aid to get through, but it needs to be enforced. Russia does now have an opportunity to demonstrate that it is compelling the Assad regime to adhere to the terms of that ceasefire, but also to demonstrate its adherence to international humanitarian law and, in particular, its duty and obligation under the Geneva Convention to protect all non-combatants.  (Applause)

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we keep hearing that there is no military solution to the war in Syria, but in fact we are all witnessing it. It is not a solution, but it is a reality that cannot be denied. Four hundred thousand civilians are trapped in Eastern Ghouta. They are starving and they are being bombed by Syrian and Russian forces, despite the UN ceasefire. Ghouta was a so-called de-escalation zone for those besieged in Aleppo, Idlib and other areas of the country in the past, but instead, the moving of people into one area seems to have put a target on their head, and the world, the EU, cannot stand by. We are also seeing the use of chemical weapons again, but what are we doing? After endless vetoes, last week we saw Russia stalling the UN Security Council Resolution for other criteria that it wanted. Clearly Putin only plays by his own cynical rules: together with Iran, it had forced an exception which allows for so-called terrorists to be targeted, despite the ceasefire. In reality that means that women, children, hospitals and schools are now accused of being terrorists, or harbouring them. This cruelty must stop. There must be, and there will be, consequences for Assad, Putin and Khamenei for what they are doing. We must do more as Europeans to reach a political solution negotiated under UN auspices. Accountability for the brutality should be our key priority. There cannot be peace without justice. But now, first and foremost, we have to actively push for guarantees that make sure humanitarian aid reaches those in need. The EU, as the biggest donor of humanitarian and development aid, must look into the terrible cases of sexual abuse of the most vulnerable refugees by aid organisation workers that are supposed to help them and not attack them. It is an absolute scandal, which we must seek an investigation into. Frankly, it is time, after the nth debate we are now having, to stop repeating empty phrases. We must take a more active and stronger political role for the EU and prioritise peace, accountability and safety for those on the run from the horrendous violence and sexual attacks that we are witnessing today. (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner. I can almost agree with what you said at the beginning of the debate. The problem for me only arises if we now have to demean more than 300 000 deaths in these seven years — men, women, children — men, women, children — in every escalation in a war that has been going on for seven years — men, women, children — Millions of people have left Syria, millions of people flee within Syria, and 13 million people are waiting for our help. If we know that 400 000 people are trapped in East Gutha, who are excluded from all medical and humanitarian care, then the question arises: what can we really do in concrete terms? I have the impression, even though I follow the discussion like this — and I do not want to insinuate anyone, but let us not define anybody by now, or if there is no danger, that anyone who is active, who lives only in Syria at all, from one side, from the other side again as a terrorist is considered? How are we going to break this cycle anyway? Everyone is ultimately a terrorist — always from the point of view of others. And the result is that the war is further intensified, that new occasions are being found, that bombs fall again, missiles fall, and that poison gas is ultimately used without anyone being punished. This isn't the first use of poison gas. Also the previous use of poison gas — what consequences have they led to? Did they mean that we, as the European Union, have really done everything possible to stop any form of arms export in the end, in order to speak out clearly against this? Have they also led us to adopt a clear stance towards some of the countries that have really actively participate in this game — and it's a bad game, it's not just a dirty game, it's a really deadly game — that we take clear positions? By that I mean Russia, but I also mean Turkey, I mean other countries, I mean Iran, and I also mean a whole range of other countries. We're talking about East Gutha. That is right and necessary, and we must immediately ensure that there is no end. We talked about Afrin last time. Now we pretend that these are two completely different things, like they don't happen in one country. But they are people in this country, and I don't care who they belong to, which ethnicity they belong to. The point is that we have to help, that we have to make sure that people can live. The last point I would like to make is that if we are here in favour of ending immediately with any form of military attack of violence against people in Syria, then, damn it, I do not understand why we have a problem within the European Union at all, about the Syrian refugees in our Union to talk. Then I demand that we do everything possible, especially the injured, to help the traumatized people and really do something for them. That would be my invitation to all of us.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, a seat worthy of the Middle Ages. Thousands of sick, injured children literally starving on the smoking rubble of an unstoppable area. A hell on earth that covers us with shame. Eastern Ghouta, the Damascus orchard, has become its cemetery. Cemetery of innocent civilians, but also of the ability of the international community, and particularly Europe, to put an end to the slaughter that bloody Syria, a country that continues to bury its children, from Kobane to Aleppo, from Raqqa yesterday to Ghouta today. The international community deserves very little its name as a community. It only notes its inability to weaken foreign godparents, those who blow on the embers of conflict and despise the rules of law and border lines. Ah! He must tremble with fear, Assad, comfortably settled in the 35,000 m2 of his presidential palace, only a few kilometers from the hospitals bombed by his army, transformed into mowers in which hundreds of wounded are piled up. In this bloody conflict, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union seems powerless, tragically powerless. It seems inaudible in New York and Geneva, it seems erased against Moscow, Tehran and Ankara. She is absent from the Astana talks. The European Union needs to do more, much more. It must do more with Russia, which, recognizes, calls the testimonies of the besieged people as “mass psychosis”. Putin, the great puppeteer, finds herself overwhelmed by his creature, Assad. It is in his interest to find a political solution at this cemetery with ever-enlarged aisles. Europe must also do more with regard to Iran. If that country wants to engage in a constructive relationship with the European Union, we expect it to play its very great influence on the Assad regime to do so cease the massacre. It is in the interest of all, including Iranians, in a logic of openness. The European Union must also do more vis-à-vis Erdoğan, who dropped his army, equipped largely by ourselves, against the Kurds of Syria in Afrin. Finally, Europe must continue to hammer loudly, but also behind the scenes, that adding war to war will not solve anything and that only a political solution can put an end to the Syrian tragedy. Europe must finally welcome the thousands of people fleeing these terrible violence and knocking on our doorstep.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, any war is horrible, especially for the civilian populations suffering it. While the Syrian regime has not been tender to its enemies, the myth of “moderate Islamist rebels” must be put to an end. Mohammed Allouche, who holds Ghouta civilians hostage with his Jaich al-Islam group, is no more moderate than the leaders of ISIS or Al-Nusra. In her letter to us last night, Mrs Mogherini speaks of Nasser Al-Hariri. But what do you hope to negotiate with this new Saudis puppet placed at the head of the “Syrian National Coalition”? Saudi Arabia, which commits atrocities in Yemen and supports and funds, directly or indirectly, a number of Islamist factions. Today, seven million people live in Damascus, where many Syrians have taken refuge. They too are bombarded daily from neighbourhoods or suburbs that are held by Islamists. The Christian district of Bab Touma is one of the privileged targets of the so-called “rebels”. Hospitals, schools and orphanages are given priority. Last week, the Red Crescent siege received more than ten shells. Among the victims are Lama Fallouh, the courageous director of the opera, who continued to work to maintain these cultural offerings that Islamist barbarians honest. Which western capital would it accept to be bombed by a rebel suburb? What can we do now to save civilians as much as possible? First, we must ensure the total defeat of the jihadists, eradicate them to the last, and transitional means either humanitarian corridors to evacuate the inhabitants of Ghouta, or temporarily leave an exit door for Islamists to return to Idlib. This is exactly what was done in Aleppo, a martyrdom city that is now reborn from its ashes.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I can only add my voice to our collective outrage at the complete disregard for human life in Eastern Ghouta, but unfortunately, beyond Eastern Ghouta, the escalation of violence is also deeply worrying. As you said in Italy, we have seen – and the United Nations has reported – almost 250 000 new displacements since December. Out of 2.4 million civilians there, half are now internally displaced. Food and shelter are also in short supply. I could certainly continue this list to include other areas, for instance, the berm along the border with Jordan, which is very close. All this gives enough evidence that we are still far from the normalisation of the situation in Syria. Unfortunately, the humanitarian dimension will therefore feature prominently again at the second conference in Brussels on Syria and the region, to take place on 24 and 25 April, where we will need to discuss how to improve our assistance and how to mobilise funding beyond this year, 2018. Needs are likely to increase further. This is the humanitarian situation on the ground and this is why the conference is an opportunity for us, as chair, to further work together towards the shared objective of supporting the Syrians in need, their host countries and communities, and promoting a sustainable political solution. But I totally agree with you, and let us also be clear that only a political solution to this crisis can end the suffering of the Syrian people. We must support and relaunch the Geneva talks because that they are the only realistic path towards peace. In the present conference we will also work to support Geneva, keeping together the humanitarian and the political track. We have been – and will be – at the forefront of the work to reach sustainable peace in Syria, with you and all the EU institutions and Member States together. I strongly believe that Syrians deserve this and we have a political and moral duty to keep Syria at the core of our common action and our common foreign policy. This is the hard reality on the ground. All of us know all the obstacles to engaging more as Europeans in this unbelievable situation, but by following this pragmatic path, we can continue our work together in order to see results on the ground as soon as possible. My last point is about sexual abuse by some organisations. Maybe you do not know that the Commission expects our partners to abide by strict ethical and professional rules, codes of conduct and principles. There is no change in our position. We definitely take a zero—tolerance approach across the board to any allegation of misconduct by organisations receiving our funding. Last week we sent a letter to all EU—funded humanitarian organisations to remind them of their strict obligations. The letter requests a detailed description of all measures that they have put in place. At the same time, we are ready to review and, if necessary, cease funding any partner who is not living up to the required high, critical ethical and professional rules and standards, as we have already established. So, we are following the situation and I strongly believe that we have to be very tough regarding any such incidents in order, above all, to sustain our reputation as humanitarians.
