name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing. — It is good that Parliament has also agreed to my request, supported by the ECR, for this debate. Europe cannot remain indifferent to what is happening in Eastern Guta. But above all, she cannot remain idle by looking at the war crimes carried out in Syria. Bashar al-Assad for seven years, all available weapons, has been carrying out murders on vulnerable civilians, pursuing a policy of ethnic cleansing and genocide on communities that have had the courage to stand up to the regime's bloody practices. Any violation of UN Security Council Resolution 2401 of 2018 must be met with a strong response from the West. Unfortunately I do not believe in assurances of support for the implementation of the resolution by Assad's Russian and Iranian allies. Lasting three days, needlessly dragged negotiations on the obvious contents of the resolutions, while at the same time, bombs were still falling on the heads of civilians, including women and children, make clear the true intentions of Damascus, Moscow and Tehran. The West, disguising itself behind hypocritical naivety and good willingness, cannot once again brand action. The human cost of such a policy is too great.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. — The humanitarian situation in Syria has hit red with hundreds of civilians losing their lives and seriously injured, and this concerns not only the situation in Ghouta but also in Afrin, another area in Syria where Turkey has been illegally invaded and engaged in Civilians, thus committing war crimes, Turkey, which is known to be openly cooperating with the jihadists. It is therefore time, as we have said in another speech in the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/2/2018, for Turkey to be indicted for war crimes to the International Criminal Court.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The war in Syria has lasted seven years and humanitarian crises have been linked. After Homs, Aleppo is the turn of Eastern Ghouta and more than 400,000 civilians to be under the fire of relentless bombardments. This situation is no longer acceptable! The European Union must act and implement concretely the strategy it adopted in March 2017. Member States and European institutions must do everything they can to put an end to the massacres and increase pressure on the regime and its allies. The UN Security Council resolution calling for a ceasefire is a first step in the right direction. It must now be enforced and that all the forces in the presence respect it. A humanitarian break is needed in order to protect civilians, allow for the safe delivery of humanitarian assistance and to evacuate the wounded. We Europeans must promote mediation and call for a solution to these escalations of violence. International law provides for the prohibition of the use of chemical weapons, safe access to humanitarian assistance and the protection of civilians. It is time for it to be respected and that civilians, especially women and children, cease to be the first victims of this bloody war.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — (PT) The CFP stands in solidarity with the men, women and children who are victims of the war of aggression against the Syrian Arab Republic, demanding an end to the hideous aggression that is the cause of the death, destruction and suffering that has been imposed on that country for seven years. Therefore, we reject the propaganda that aims to whiten the aggression and its responsible, as well as the real goals of those who make it, defend or promote it. Having created, financed and armed Daesh, divided Iraq and promoted war in Syria, the United States of America and its allies - in particular Israel, Turkey and France - seek to overcome the defeat inflicted on their terrorist groups and now take up, in their own hands, the objective of dividing the Syria, just like they did in Iraq and Libya. Once again, they rely on a gigantic media operation that reproduces war propaganda to support their goals.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council statement concerning the informal meeting of the European Council on 23 February 2018 (2018/2575 (RSP)). Last Friday, I explained to the informal European Council our proposal on the composition of this Parliament in the next parliamentary term and our positions on other institutional issues and on next multiannual financial framework. I thank President Tusk for having wanted to inform me yesterday about the discussions that took place during the working breakfast. I am pleased to announce that the proposal on the future composition of Parliament, which we approved by a large majority during the last part-session in Strasbourg, has been welcomed in a positive way by the Heads of State and Government, who judged it sensible and balanced. So I would like to thank once again the rapporteurs Danuta Maria Hübner and Pedro Silva Pereira for their excellent work. To the Council, I stressed that Parliament's proposal ensures that no country will lose seats compared to the current situation and takes into account the political need to have a more reduced Parliament in following the exit of the United Kingdom, the need to adapt the composition of Parliament to the demographic changes in recent years in the various Member States, and the opportunity to keep a margin for future allocation of seats to newly accessed countries. I am convinced that this proposal will get swift approval from the European Council, not least because the decision currently in force, which is from 2013, applies only to the current legislature and So we need to adopt a new one in good time for next year's European elections. Questioned on the subject, I also explained that in its proposal Parliament did not take up the idea of establishing transnational lists, a suggestive idea but which, for the moment, does not have the support of a majority within the Assembly. Heads of state and government are likely to return to the issue in the future, perhaps in the run-up to the 2024 election. I also recalled that Parliament submitted a proposal to revise the electoral law as early as 2015 and we hope that the European Council will at least approve the parties on which there is consensus on time useful for the next election. As you know, the Council also discussed Spitzenkandidaten. I stressed the broadly majority position in Parliament that the introduction of this practice in the 2014 elections was an important step on the way to a more political Europe, from which you don't have to go back. Not only should the practice be maintained, but it should be improved in order to strengthen the legitimacy of the Commission through a fiduciary link with the stronger Parliament. If we want to reduce the distances that exist between the institutions and the citizens today, we must give them the convinced feeling that we are part of the decisions on the future government of the European Union. This is, however, a matter which remains problematic for the European Council, since it is a constant right to find ways to save the prerogatives given to the Council by the Treaty. But I believe that it is possible to come to an agreement. At the informal European Council we also discussed the new multiannual financial framework. I said that the Europe we wish must be able to have the necessary financial resources to achieve the objectives we have agreed. I reaffirmed that the post-2020 budget must be a political budget, based not on merely redistributive logic but on a clear strategy and precise objectives. We must first make political choices and only after establishing the budgetary resources necessary to achieve them, not the other way around. I said that Parliament's priorities are those of our citizens and it is clear that the new The financial framework must allow the Union to emerge strengthened by the crises of the recent past and face new challenges, such as efficient control of migration, combating youth unemployment and internal and external security, so also the fight against terrorism and of course the issue of defence and combating climate change. Next to the new challenges remain traditional ones, such as youth unemployment, which remains a serious problem. We all agree that the new financial framework should be aimed at fostering well-being, sustainable long-term economic growth, quality employment and innovation, as well as which, of course, to promote the economy through social and territorial cohesion. I stressed that Parliament also recognises the fundamental importance of a modern and environmentally friendly common agricultural policy, which can ensure food security and guarantee the survival of rural population. During the debate, I also stressed how important it is for us to focus on our own resources. I said that the European Parliament has a position that points to 1.3% of the European GDP, and therefore more money in the budget, but I insisted on the issue of own resources, as we had also agreed during the informal meeting I had with the chairmen of the groups. I also indicated what they are: web tax, environmental import tax and speculative financial transaction tax — I cited these three examples. As regards the timetable, I have illustrated the majority position within Parliament, namely the desire to have a vote in the House on the budget before the next European elections. The technical times are there, we will have to make the most of the political ones. I said that we are ready to do whatever is possible if this becomes our common goal. These, in summary, are the things I referred to name and on behalf of Parliament after meeting once again informally with all the chairmen of the groups, precisely because, given the delicacy of the matter and its importance, I preferred truly make more and more the majority spokesman in this House saying, where there were majority choices, that they were choices made by majority.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, one would almost assume that there’s an election going on somewhere. Thank you very much, Mr President. I can be very brief on the institutional issues because the Commission concurs fully with how you reflected the discussion at the summit. I want to comment on a few points. Spitzenkandidaten are apparently now part of the Italian language as well as of the English language. The other German word that I know is in both the Italian and the English languages is angst, but probably there’s no relation between the two. What do I have to say about this? As far as the Commission is concerned, this is something that was done in 2014 and therefore is established. We at the Commission have to add that the Treaty is leads the way here, so the Commission is, if you could put it that way, a child of Parliament and the European Council. So of course we want to strengthen our position in Parliament and our democratic legitimacy, as you’ve explained, Mr President, but we also have to face the reality that the European Council has a say as well. What we said in our communication is that it does not follow that the person who heads the political group that ends up with the most seats in the European Parliament automatically becomes a Commission President. A majority in the European Parliament might be a factor. Somebody else might be chosen if they secured a majority in the European Parliament and could also be carried by the European Council. That is how way we have put it in our communication. The leaders did not decide, for now, on the size of the next Commission, although the 2013 decision means that they will have to come back to this issue before the next Commission is put in place, and the issue of a transnational constituency has also been left open. I know that the majority in Parliament is not in favour, but the matter was discussed and we will surely come back to it ahead of the 2024 elections; and I must point out that the leaders do not have much of an appetite at present for the idea of a double-hatted President of the Commission and the European Council.  Finally, I just want to welcome the renewed interest which the leaders have expressed in different forms of outreach and engagement with our citizens. We are really looking forward to sharing our experience with Member States, especially in view of the new impetus that Member States have given to this. We’ve run, I think, 478 citizens’ dialogues so far and before the end of our term we want to do 500 more.  The second topic on the agenda was our future budget. Discussion among the leaders was less abrasive than some might have expected, and that should be welcomed: they all understand that at the end of the day we will need a budget. Many Member States expressed a willingness to increase the level of their contributions. Some did not. At the same time the Commission made it clear that savings on redeployments would be needed for some parts of the budget if new priorities were going to be properly funded. When we, as politicians, formulate new priorities, we also have to face the fact that other issues will then have to be deprioritised, and that has financial consequences. So this is going to be a major task. We will make our formal proposals for the future budget by the beginning of May at the latest. At last week’s meeting, we stressed the need to decide on the final deal and yes, in some cases, agreed trade-offs between different deserving causes before the next European elections. But I also note that opinions diverge on that point and that many people would like to have the decision after the European elections. I see Mr Verhofstadt, who has also, if I’m correct, expressed his view in favour of having the decision after the elections.  Why do we want to take the decision before the elections? Because the current MFF was decided upon only at the very end of 2013, which meant that the programmes putting it into effect could not be brought into being until 2014, so the first year was actually lost when it came to actually getting money out into the real world, which we need urgently to do, to get money invested in our society in order to make sure that convergence starts happening again in Europe. One of the fundamental threats to the future of the European Union is divergence within and between Member States, and we need to put  taxpayers’ money to good use to restart the engine of convergence in our Union. Of course the benefits of EU membership go far beyond the budget. Some of these benefits can be quantified, others not. I think that we should be talking more in terms of the EU dividend, which is not just a balance sheet, but much more than that. Perhaps if we can talk more in terms of EU dividends we can also come to an agreement on how the EU budget should be structured in the future. Not everybody can recognise that this is in everybody’s interest.  (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I regret that Donald Tusk is not with us today, because I have had a new experience when discussing the informal Council experience. I am quite fine with the outcome of the meeting on Friday. That is why I regret that he is not present with us, because, first of all, in the preparations for 2019, the EPP Group is very thankful that we can agree on the composition and that we have legal certainty for 2019, which is important. Secondly, as regards the Spitzenkandidat, the role is clear. The Council is insisting on its role, which is legally defined in the Lisbon Treaty, and that is fine. However, I also see that the same personalities who stressed, in the informal meeting on Friday, the role of the Council are part of the party meetings, and there they are supporting the process to nominate candidates in the party format. My party will do this in Helsinki in November. That is agreed upon and that is what we will do. Frans Timmermans explained once again what parliamentary democracy means. It is not the biggest group which will have the chance, but only the candidate who can organise a majority will have the chance to be elected as Commission President. However, one thing is again crystal clear: nobody will be elected from this Parliament and from the next Parliament who was not, before the elections, put forward as a candidate from a democratic party. That is a principle. It is fixed and it has now been approved.  The innovation that is ahead of us is that we need not only candidates, but we also really need attractive programmes from the different political parties to show people an alternative and to make a really European campaign. On MFF, things are on the right path. It was a constructive discussion. First of all, we have to make the EU more effective and spend money in a more effective way. Then there are the new tasks on the table, and we will need fresh new money.  I sometimes hear the argument that the EU will be smaller. Dear friends, when I look at the tasks on the table – the demands for the African Fund, for the Defence Fund and for strengthening Frontex – I do not see how Europe will be smaller in the next MFF. There are lot of tasks on the table which have to be financed. The last point I want to make in my intervention today is about the most important discussion this week on Brexit, because tomorrow Theresa May will make a speech on this subject. When I look to the outcome and the developments in the last weeks in the British debate, the key question is still what the new relationship between the European Union and Great Britain will look like. One principle is clear for us: a country outside the EU cannot have the same standards and the same rights as a country inside the European Union. It is also clear for us that an endless transition period is not acceptable to us. That is why we welcome today’s presentation of a possible Leave Treaty. One point is still open, and that is the question of what these long-term relationships will look like. We need clarity on this. We hope that, when we listen tomorrow to Theresa May, we will have more clarity, for example on the future relationship with the City of London and how the Open Skies will look in the future. There are many questions on the table and we need a clear idea.  I have to pick up one message we received from the UK Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson. When I look at what he said, especially on the question of the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland, I must say that a politician should try to solve problems and not create problems. Don’t play with the achievements of the past; don’t play with the peace process; don’t play with the future of the young generation in Northern Ireland. The EPP will be on the side of the Irish people: we will not accept a hard border, and will not risk the peace process. That is what we want to achieve. Europe is ready. We hope that London is also already.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behold of the S&D Group. — Mr President, thank you for informing us about what Mr Tusk told you to regard the conclusion. Frans Timmermans on behold of the Commission, thank you for drawing the conclusions, a lot of which we share, not all of them but a lot. Buy the main question today is: where is the European Council? I haven't met the European Council on the floors of this chamber. I have not seen them here. Thanks to our Bulgarian colleagues, there is not even an empty chair and there is not even an elephant in the room. There's just Nothing. I do not regret that, my dear colleague Manfred Weber — I find it a scandal — because this is about the future of Europe, and where is the President of the European Council? He will learn to take this House seriously, and he and his colleagues will learn to take this Chamber of European Parliamentarians seriously because it's about our common future, and we will not give in on these children of procedures. Europe's future is about money — of course too. Therefore, it is completely incomprehensible why so little comes out of this. These informal summits have been introduced to make it easier for you to speak more confidently. But what is the result? What are the formal summits supposed to look like when the informal summits are already giving so little to light? Of course, we agree to take on new tasks. We know, of course, that Europe needs to take care of a decent refugee policy, that we need to ensure that migration issues are sensible. And that we take care of security, old security issues — new security issues. This is our clear position. But how can this be done without additional funding? Where is the commitment of the ladies and gentlemen in the European Council to allow us more of this? And in particular: Where is the question of own resources? Thank you, Mr President, for mentioning this again, that is how we have discussed. But why — it is in the hands of the governments of the European Council — not finally a financial transaction tax that pays into Europe's budget? Why not finally get a tax on the multinationals who do business in e-commerce without paying decent taxes? It is high time for this, and that is exactly what has to happen, exactly what has to be implemented. We are waiting for this. The European Council says that it does not agree or cannot guarantee that the top candidates will also be proposed at the end of the day or that the top candidates will be elected by the top candidate. We have to say to Mister Tusk and the Colleagues: We could not care less. Why? We could not care less, because the question of whether the European parties nominate top candidates is not the property of the European Council, but of European civil society, and the parties and citizens will take a decision on this, and not the governments and ladies of the European Parliament. Rat, it won't be like this! That is why I make it very clear that this House has undertaken not to choose anyone who has not faced this democratic competition for programmes and for people. We in the Socialist Group are certainly not going to do so because we were the pioneers of this process. We will not choose anyone who escapes democratic competition. We will no longer approve of backroom events. We want democracy for European citizens.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Just for your information, this was an informal European Council and the President of the Council is not obliged to come and report to Parliament. It's his faculty, then political opportunity is another. I say this just for information.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, with friends like that, who needs enemies? Can I come back another time? (Referring to remarks made by members of the EFDD Group.) So what came out of last Friday’s Council meeting? A clear signal that there is still a long way to go to persuade Member States to sign up to a bigger budget and also how to select the next Commission President. A number of EU Member State governments know that their voters do not want them to simply sign blank cheques to fund the ambitions of the Commission and the leaders of two or three of the larger Member States. Members of this House can no longer dismiss those voters, those politicians and those governments who question the agenda of political integration or simply label them as being anti-EU, for once you step outside the EU bubble, it is clear that the call for more Europe, whatever the problem, is the voice of an elite, not the voice of citizens in many of our countries.  National governments and voters want to feel that they get value out of the EU for what they pay in. Not all of them want to see a 1950s agenda of political integration. On the whole, the voters want to see a budget that is well managed and matches their priorities, a budget that provides security and well—functioning asylum and immigration systems, and a budget that encourages a cleaner environment, innovation and job creation. But – and members of the ECR Group would want me to be very clear on this point – a budget should not be used to buy solidarity, to bribe Member States into taking asylum seekers, or to control or punish the actions of individual Member States, especially when the Member State pushing for the policy itself broke the rules and, in the process, nearly destroyed the EU’s asylum system.  So, as President Tusk has already admitted, agreeing a budget before the next election is probably unrealistic, but even if all of you here and the EU institutions cannot agree on a budget, those politicians facing their electorates in 2019 should all be clear about what modernising the budget really means, about how the EU will face the massive hole after the UK leaves, and whether the EU budget will be one of coercion rather than cooperation between 27 equal Member States. So the ECR Group’s question to the Council and the Commission is simple: Is the EU facing a future where decisions continue to be made by all 27 Member States, or a future where decisions are dictated by the few?  (Applause)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all we have to thank Mr Kamall for all the recommendations he is giving for the next budget, in which Britain will no longer be involved. Thank you Mr Kamall. Secondly, I think we have to pay you, Mr President, a double salary in February because you have taken over the role of Mr Tusk today and that is significant because you, Mr Timmermans, spoke of the idea of ‘one hat’ in the European Union, and we have proved that it is possible for the Commission to double-hat for the Council. The only other thing, maybe, is that you can go over to the other side once, and then come back. But I will not go over the whole discussion that you had in that informal Council about Spitzenkandidaten and transnational lists. I have already said what I think about that, namely that you are making an enormous strategic mistake. You are endangering the Spitzenkandidat concept by not embedding it in a democratic process in a transnational list. The reality is that the Spitzenkandidat continues to be a toy of political parties and again between the Council on the one hand and Parliament on the other, but there is no legitimacy on the democratic front. Transnational lists provide precisely that – putting the Spitzenkandidat concept into a democratic process so it is our people who decide who is elected, and then the European Council could no longer object to the outcome of such an election. But okay: Rome was not built, as you know Mr President, in a day, and the same is true of transnational democracy. We will come back to this in 2024. On the issue of the budget, I have been involved three times in the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), twice as a member of the Council and once as a Member of the European Parliament, and my fear is very simple, Mr Timmermans: that it will be business as usual. It will be a budget for seven years in which the next Parliament will have no say – no say in five years! Secondly, I fear it will be again a list of 50-60 rebates, exceptions, earmarkings, and exceptional monies to buy the support of all the Member States, and 80% of it will be money paid by the Member States going back to the Member States, and not going to the new priorities that we have – border management, innovation, migration, defence and things like that. So my appeal to all the political groups represented here is: let’s break the cycle of this European budget. Let’s make an agreement, together with the Commission, on the priorities. Secondly, on conditionality: will we continue to hear, for example, that Mr Orban is misusing European money to build a football stadium in his town, or to make his friends and family multimillionaires on the basis of European money? No! Let us establish conditionality: if you don’t accept the values, you don’t need our money. That must be the principle. And thirdly, on the issue of our responsibility. This is the only Parliament, colleagues, which has no say about income: the only one worldwide which has nothing to say about revenue. That has to change, and that means Article 311 of the Treaty, once there is a change to the Treaty, will need to incorporate co-decision by the European Parliament on income. My plea to you – and it is more important for me than the period of five years or of seven years – is that, for once, we have can cohesion in this Parliament, unity in this Parliament, on our refusal ever to accept an MFF without co-decision by Parliament on the issue of revenue. That said, if we do not decide before the next election, it will not be the fault of this Parliament. I’m pretty sure that the European Council will not be capable of reaching agreement on the next MFF before the elections.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Verhofstadt, thank you very much. We want more power for the European Parliament. Not for the President of the European Parliament, but for the European Parliament!

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, the results of the informal Council unfortunately confirm that the Union continues the same neoliberal policies, circumventing proclaimed principles and the interests of the peoples. In relation to the multiannual financial framework, instead of discussing solidarity measures to address the refugee crisis, it was proposed to increase expenditure on the creation of Fortress Europe, by strengthening borders and patrols. Union leaders also agreed to increase investment in military industry rather than proposing measures to support the real economy, to promote funds and investments for social and regional cohesion, to combat poverty, employment and creation of new quality jobs. These policies which they promote will not benefit the people but will lead to new warfare and new waves of refugees. The current humanitarian crisis in Syria is, I think, typical. With regard to the European Union's relations with Turkey, the plea following President Tusk's informal Council to put an end to the violations in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Aegean is positive but not enough. Turkey has prevented a drilling rig of the European Italian company ENI from proceeding to a drilling in the Cyprus Exclusive Economic Zone and continues to violate international law and Law of the Sea with illegal Navtex. It continues the flagrant violations of the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus. We therefore expect concrete solidarity from the European Union and more drastic measures, i.e. we expect pressure to be exerted on Turkey to stop illegal actions immediately, to respect the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus and to support the resumption of talks from the point that were left in the last talks in Crans-Montana, so that we can finally to lead us to the solution of the Cyprus problem. I would like to recall that on the question of future gas management there have already been convergence between the two leaders of the two communities since 2010, to which UN Secretary-General António Guterres also referred in his latest report. These convergences resolve the issue in the interest of the entire Cypriot people, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, since the solution of the Cyprus problem and the reunification of Cyprus will both benefit from natural gas.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, how we set up our long—term budget obviously reflects how we want to deal with the European Union overall, and there I do see some cause for concern. Some Member States say they just want to have enough money for their national pet projects, they want money for their farmers, they want internal security and external security, a lot of things, but they also want to pay less money, and that simply cannot work because a strong and active European Union needs resources. That does not mean that we can just spend it how we want. We have to be careful with where we invest taxpayers’ money, and I can think of quite a few cases where we can save on some of them, from big pie—in—the—sky projects like ITER to the way we choose to travel ourselves, dear colleagues. There are also plenty of examples of how EU money is being misspent in the Member States, and there we need more control and more guidance before the damage is done. EU money always needs to be spent well and in the interests of the people living in Europe, and it must never, ever contribute to corruption. The fight between Member States about who should pay what shows that we need to put the EU’s budget on a more independent footing. Own resources should be introduced now and we think they should be done in a way that enables us to actually tax and take the money from what is destroying our very own habitat. The budget will always reflect what we value most. It is a tool to finance the vision that we have for this place where we all live, for the future, and we must put the money where we think the EU should be going. We should not forget either that we have actually agreed some important international commitments. I am thinking of the Paris Agreement and climate protection, sustainable development goals, to name just a few.  But money alone does not bring happiness. What we also need in the Union is a strengthened European debate and to bring decision-making closer to EU citizens, and that is where the whole discussion about the leading candidates comes in. Sure, that concept does not solve all the problems that we have, but it was – and it is – a vital step forward for a more accountable Commission and, more generally, a more accountable European Union. If Member States were to give up that progress because they were afraid that they themselves might not win or because they prefer to have some backroom deals, then this really is a slap in the face of European democracy, and whoever goes down that path should not be surprised if Europe herself gets up at some point and slaps back.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this debate is of course taking place because you have to talk about how you are going to fill the shortfall of money left when Britain leaves the European Union. I will say something about Brexit. What the Commission is proposing is not a withdrawal agreement so much as a ‘UK not really leaving at all’ agreement – leaving in name, but not in reality. You intend to impede and delay that process and overturn it if at all possible. Now I do not blame you, because you do not want us to leave and you have no incentive whatsoever to help us do it, but I do blame the British Prime Minister. What Britain needs now is a leader with the courage and spirit of a Boadicea, and instead we have got ‘Theresa the Appeaser’. In the referendum, the British people voted to leave the European Union, and what that means is that we don’t give any more money to the European Union. It means we are not bound by European Union law. It means we don’t have open borders and it means that we are not subject to the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice. To make that happen, the Government should take control of the process. The British Government should stop asking the European Union how it might leave please, and it should start telling them how it’s going to work.  (Applause)

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, the new multiannual budget is coming and the Commission wants more EU, more money for migration, more money for enlargement, more money for its own army. But now that England is leaving the EU, there is less money, much less: between EUR 14 and EUR 25 billion a year. Most Member States, as we heard on Friday, do not want to pay more. So Mr Verhofstadt, the ALDE Group, calls for direct EU taxes. That solves the problem. You don't see it in the national budget, but the citizen does pay for it. The other Europhilic parties here join in. The civilian is screwed again. Citizens pay for this failing project. I say to you: the EU should not spend more, but less. The budget should not be higher, but lower. The citizen should not pay more, but less. So the priorities are clear: no new EU tasks, but less EU, no direct taxes, less EU payments, and preferably not an enlargement of the EU, but a lifting.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr. President! President Tajani is now unfortunately leaving, and I wanted to ask him and Commissioner Timmermans, in connection with the informal deliberation of Heads of Government and State. One of the topics was the long-term budget of the European Union, and even though this issue is not raised here, which is of great importance for Hungary and the Visegrád countries, I would like you to do so in an additional way, and I will ask you this. This is the following: According to the press, especially on the proposal by Mrs Merkel, they want to divert cohesion money, catch-up money and possibly other resources from Member States that say no to mass migration, mass immigration. What is the truth of this? Do they have such a plan? We need to know this only because there will be elections in Hungary on 8 April, and there will be ongoing debating this issue of migration, silly and uninformed to those who say that the European Union is constantly pushing this issue. He's constantly terrorizing us with a wide variety of means. If we look only at the various reports of this meeting, we can see it, and there is also this terrorisation with certain money. What is the truth of this? Or have you ever passed this? Or you do not talk about it because you are afraid that the electorate might be affected by this in Hungary, because you would see that this is indeed the most important priority for you, you do not give it down, and you want to bring Hungary and the Visegrád countries to their knees by all means. I look forward to Mr Tajani's reply, if possible, but also definitely the reply from Mr Timmermans.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Let me make a few remarks. If I have just heard the last country being banged, I do not believe that no country will be banged if you point out that the order of the European Union, in particular the rule of law, is being safeguarded. These are principles that we should not argue about, and this is not to be understood as underpressure setting. But I would like to say one thing about the European Council and ultimately only address one issue. This is the question, one year before the European elections, how can we bring our political project even more clearly to the electorate. There has been a crucial point in the Treaty of Lisbon, which we practiced last time in the election of the President of the Commission, but which has not yet been fully brought into the political debate by the political parties in the same way: that is the question of the top candidate. We would like the Treaty to proceed in the future — and we will not allow the European Council to defend its own interests in its backrooms. We would like to note that the head of the European administration will in future be elected by the electorate through the European Parliament, as provided for in the Treaty, and this is not a clearance between heads of government. If we do not bring this Europe to the citizens in the crucial positions, then this Europe will not have a chance in the long run. Following this statement by the European Council, we should make it clear that the European Parliament will fight for this right over the next fifteen months. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Ask about the procedure of the “blue card”. — You are always so eloquently committed to the top candidate. Now I've been on the road to the election campaign too: can you explain to me why I didn't see a single poster of your top candidate Juncker throughout Germany during the 2014 election campaign?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — I will give you two answers. Firstly, I said that it has been practiced; it needs to get much better. In the meantime, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrat) has changed its statute and we will elect a top candidate in November, so that this will no longer work I'm assuming other parties will do the same. On the second question, it was probably the case that at the time you only looked at posters from the AfD — which you have left — and therefore did not have a look for democratic candidates.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, at their last meeting some leaders proved that they are not really understanding what a budget to pave the way for a better future in the European Union should be. Of course we need to cope with new challenges – for example, managing migration means Europe delivering on better cooperation in development and peace-building with its entire neighbourhood – that’s for sure. But Europe also need to be ambitious on programmes which have proved to be a success, such as Erasmus, the programme for science and technology or the youth initiative. Most of all, we need to ensure strong means to provide social and territorial cohesion in Europe, because without that there is no unity among European citizens. This also means – because convergence is a central problem for us – that, when it comes to the eurozone, we need to include a fiscal capacity in the upcoming Multiannual Financial Framework. So how can we deliver on all this? Well, the answer is easy. We have to accept, once and for all, that we need new own resources to finance our common budget. And there is a further matter on which the leaders were too shy, namely the right way to understand European democracy, because some of them are hesitant about the need for European parties to put up their own candidates in European elections, presenting their own programmes in such a way that citizens can choose not only legislators but also executive power. From our side, this is very clear. The Parliament … (The President asked the speaker to conclude) I have two minutes. (The President urged the speaker to conclude briefly) Usually I am very precise, Mr President. Parliament will elect a President of the European Commission only if that person is properly presented to the electorate. From our side this is very clear.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Mr President, let me reflect on the withdrawal agreement which was published yesterday. For me this is a very clear sign that Brexit is a declaration of war on European industry, not only on British industry. Are you aware of the fact that, economically, Brexit is equivalent to 19 countries leaving the European Union at the same time? There are very complex logistical supply chains in danger – customer relationships, supplier relationships – and, in the end, Britain will become the largest British customer. I wonder why we are continuing to try to punish Britain for their decision. Instead the Commission should focus on placing the interests of the European Union as priority number one. Those interests are very similar to Britain’s interests. Any deal which is good for British industry is also a very good deal for European industry, and that is why I believe we should change the Commission’s priorities. Let’s make sure that British industry has access to the European common market as before and, likewise, let’s make sure that common market industries have the same access to British industry.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The starting point of the debate was the decision of the British people to leave this European Union. So far — so good. The decision has been made. But what does the European Union do? Not to simply cross out the 73 seats that the British held here, to signal to the European taxpayer public that they are also prepared to save appropriately. No, you claw 27 of these 73 seats to save away and inflates this Parliament once again. This is a wrong decision because, if this Parliament should be able to work and be effective and accepted, it should be resized accordingly. Similarly, with the Commission, where there are corresponding fixings here in the area of the Treaty of Lisbon, should reduce this Commission by at least one third. And what do you do? A unanimous decision by the Council to leave this Commission, which was originally a large size of 27 members. A false signal. If this European Union and this project wants to reach agreement and acceptance, then we have to resize.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Mr President, colleagues at the beginning of this month we voted, by a large majority, on the new composition of the European Parliament for the European elections of 2019. We reduced the size of the House from 751 to 705 seats and proposed a composition that is fair, based on objective principles, respects the EU’s Treaty and adheres to the principle of digressive proportionality. I appreciate that during the informal European Council meeting, our proposal was broadly supported. Let me however underline the fact that, after a formal decision is taken by the European Council, it will have to come back to the European Parliament so that we can have a final vote as part of the consent procedure. This should happen by summer this year. On the issue of the Spitzenkandidaten, I wish to reiterate that this process, endorsed again by a large majority of this Chamber three weeks ago, is a matter of principle and of interinstitutional balance and cooperation for us. We see this process as a reinforcement of the democratic accountability of the European institutions and as an enhancement of the role of the European political parties. So I trust that the European Council will pursue this democratic advance with a view to helping citizens develop the feeling of ownership of Europe.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies of the Bulgarian presidency, ladies and gentlemen, in the discussions now open on the finances of the European Union, President Juncker invited us a few days ago to step out of accounting logic. Of course, we must maintain our budgetary seriousness and, however, we must indeed embrace the debate on the future of Europe through this discussion. Then let us get out of sterile oppositions, from competing between cohesion and agriculture or, worse, from situations where solidarity is sacrificed for the sake of security. Let us ask ourselves what we want to do together; this Parliament, with its 750 Members, is about to do so. Climate agreement, social pillar, convergence, youth, sustainable development goals, investment for the future: we have our course. It is therefore not a question of cutting in the CAP or in cohesion, but, on the contrary, of allowing them to evolve to achieve these objectives. The CAP must become the instrument of food autonomy that respects soils, water and those who work in it, and of course for us who feed it. As for cohesion, this is our key to converging towards development for all peoples, all regions, environmental and social development. I call on the Council, although it is absent, to accept Parliament's outstretched hand. It increases the chances of consent or, if you prefer, reduces the risk of his veto. Let us define with the Bulgarian Presidency the modalities of our method of discussion. Let us leave until the Commission's proposal on 2 May to reach a shared agreement on a new multiannual financial framework.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, the commander in chief of the Allied forces in Europe, General Breedlove, warned that Russian forces that have placed missiles in the Black Sea can control the entire Black Sea area and install nuclear weapons in the area. Another warning came recently, a few months ago, from the head of military counterintelligence in Germany who again said “The Russian Federation is not a friend to us and we must be prepared for anything.” Romania has the second largest external border in the European Union. We have a border with the Republic of Moldova where Soviet troops are still stationed, we have a border with Serbia that is practically under Russian control, we have a border with Ukraine, with the Black Sea, implicitly with the Russian-occupied Crimea. We have information on Russia's interference in elections in many democratic states through money and false propaganda. The war against democracy has begun. We need to increase funding for the security of the Union, increase funding and strengthen European agencies that fight terrorism.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, today’s draft Brexit document is just a work of pure fantasy, but it is also dangerous one, particularly on Northern Ireland. We will decide on our borders for our citizens. To paraphrase Margaret Thatcher, we have not voted successively to take back control of our frontiers in Britain only to see them reimposed at a European level, in a European superstate, exercising a new dominance from Brussels. No, no, no. The UK is not for turning. And the only common sense that has been spoken in this Chamber today was the ECR’s Mr Henkel. What matters is people’s jobs, industry and their GDP.  Your companies want to have a free-trade deal with us. Our companies want to have a free-trade deal with you. If you do not want to see this Parliament split apart – because that is what is happening because of the populist vote: my side of the Parliament is actually gaining control of governments or being in opposition – then I suggest you listen to Mr Henkel if you don’t listen to us.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! Before the meeting of the European Council, the President asked three questions in his letter on the first priorities, second the size of the budget, third of the calendar. After the meeting of the European Council, we received a message on which we wonder whether this is good or bad news for Parliament. As regards the contents, we in the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament have tried to answer these questions, also assuming that they will fall later. In our position, which we adopted the day before the European Council, we have clearly stated how we want to take new priorities, and we agree with the European Council on this issue. Secondly, we have talked about the size of the budget, and here the reaction of the European Council is not yet clear, which is good news because it means that there is no rejection of a proposal today. As for the calendar, for today there is also no clear answer, which we also consider a rather positive sign than a negative sign. In other words, the European Council has left the door open and a serious debate with the European Parliament begins.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President! We are debating the Council meeting today, as we regularly do. Once again, we are criticising the fact that expectations have not been met or only partially met. At home, we will then face disappointed expectations. People will then say lapidary that the EU will not work. Things have become too confusing for people, and because no responsibilities can be established, scepticism and rejection often occurs. This time, the Heads of State and Government would have been in their hands to take an important step. Whatever one may be on the top candidate principle, it is definitely an essential contribution to creating accountability. The representatives of the Member States have preferred to postpone everything on the long bench, rather than making concrete proposals. What is particularly disappointing, however, is the fact that there are heads of state — such as those of France — who can't normally go too fast.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President the latest agenda and informal summit are important stepping stones towards a better and more inclusive Europe. The open and frank exchange of ideas on the future of Europe is how democracy works on a truly European scale. Not all ideas are good ideas, and only a fraction will become reality. Personally, I do not believe in the idea of a transnational list, but I think it’s important that we had the debate and found a clear majority, both in Parliament and in Council, of the same opinion. On the budget, it’s clear that it’s not set in stone. We need to adopt the budget so it represents the real needs and concerns of our citizens. We wholeheartedly support additional EU spending to stop illegal migration, trafficking and to counter human smugglers and criminal networks who prey on those who are already most vulnerable. But at the same time Europe cannot and will not isolate itself from the world. We need to step up our engagement with and in Africa. The MFF should be a cornerstone in a new Marshall Plan for Africa, so we can help those who are most vulnerable more, help them sooner and help them where they are.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: — Mr President, for those who advocate the progress of the European project, the conclusions of the last informal Council are a cause for concern, but one thing the Council did well in endorsing the proposal that was adopted here in this Parliament on the recomposition of the European Parliament and which was adopted by a large majority and in that I had the honor of being a co-rapporteur. On a difficult issue, Parliament proved that it was capable of generating fair solutions and broad consensus. The Council would do well to listen more to this Parliament on other issues, such as the Multiannual Financial Framework. The Commissioner has told us here that one of the greatest threats to the future of the European project is the worsening of differences. There are, today, those in the Council and the Commission advocate cuts in cohesion and convergence policies. It would be good that this European Parliament should be heard there too.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last week's informal Council discussed, among other things, the forthcoming multiannual financial framework for our Europe. It is a very important discussion because it has to do with the future, it has to do with the future of our businesses, research, work, our young people, the environment, that is, it has to do with the idea that we have of Europe from here on, in the next seven years. To do this we need — we have written it in our papers, we told the Commission and the Council — for a strong budget, a budget that is able to respond to expectations of citizens, that they are able to meet the expectations of our businesses, our world of the economy, our world of work. In order to have a strong budget, we have to have European resources, very strong own resources: on this I feel that there is very little push on the part of the Council and that there is no willingness to go forward. On the other hand, we believe that we need to release resources for the Member States and, at the same time, have a Europe that can provide for at least 50% of its own needs, of its own budget. These are the expectations not only of this Parliament, but are the expectations for the future of the citizens and citizens of Europe.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I too should like to concentrate on the issues of European representation in one minute. But when Erdoğan intervenes in the southern sea of Cyprus, which is also the sea of the European Union, we have no choice but to discuss this matter. How many crimes does this regime have to commit in order for us to act at last? He continues the illegal occupation of the Northern part of Cyprus. It broke down the rule of law within Turkey. It imprisons all opposing views. It exterminates the Kurds and every other people within Turkey. He has been allied for so many years with the jihadists whom, as we all know, he is funding and using them today in the attack on Afrin. The last event, of course, is the raid on the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus and the Aegean Sea. I think that if we stick to condemning statements and words this time, we will have failed and soon regret it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, I think that the European Council quite rightly decided and condemned Turkey with a hard language for its unacceptable actions in the Cyprus Exclusive Economic Zone. I believe that these actions are directed directly against the European Union. When violating the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus, it violates the external borders and maritime borders of the European Union. When it targets the energy plans of Cyprus, it targets and hits the European Union itself. When Turkey obstructs European companies such as ENI and TOTAL, it affects European Union companies, it damages the EU's own interests. Turkey today, with all these provocative actions, is a challenge and an insult to the European Union itself. Since Turkey only understands the language of sanctions and measures, I think it is imperative that we rethink any Euro-Turkish relations, the upgrading of a customs union that is inconceivable and unacceptable, the liberalisation of visas for Turkish citizens, but also something else. The most important and most importantly, on which the European Parliament also has a say, is the financing of funds from the European Funds. This Turkey needs measures and convictions.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — I also want to comment briefly on the informal European Council meeting of 27 leaders. So we are already getting used to Brexit, unfortunately. I agree with the Vice-President of the Commission that there is a need to clearly sign up to the priorities for the following EU financial framework. Those priorities are to be security, to tackle migration, and I am very pleased that the European Council has signed up to Erasmus+ because education, youth mobility, that is the future of the EU. Also, the condition for Turkey to take place next month in Varna, Turkey's activities in the Mediterranean and Syria must be discontinued, and human rights should also be added, since jailing journalists and academics is unacceptable to us. If this is the process of Spitzenkandidaten, then I believe that the agreement here is more than an automatic rule.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to focus on these additional issues to say that the composition is very balanced and I am very happy that there is a positive response. Secondly, I am also very happy that transnational lists were not considered. This is very important because, for true federalists and true pro-Europeans, there is no experience of a joint and single constituency in the United States, the Federal Republic of Germany or in Switzerland. This would create an imbalance between the countries. If you want to change the rules in Parliament on the balance of the countries, you have to change it first in the Council and then we will see.  Finally, I fully understand the position of the Council in the Spitzenkandidaten issue, but they also have to understand ours, because we have to approve the candidate, we have to approve their programme, and we have to approve the College. We have three opportunities to reject the Council’s proposal.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, this informal Council in February has dealt with the multiannual financial framework, Turkey and even Syria and, of course, Brexit. But this European Parliament is doing very well in emphasizing the opportunity that the Council risks losing by letting an unavoidable meeting with a Europe better than this, because the proposal adopted by the European Parliament which attempts to link the Commission presidency to the top of the list of each large family politics is a civic, citizen and European culture commitment. Many are also voting in favour of transnational lists, because they mean the beginning of a pan-European response to the need for pan-European citizenship and representation in this European Parliament. But in no case can the Council miss the opportunity to relaunch Europe and remove it from this state of decline, if not paralysis, in which it has unfortunately been in recent years. Spitzenkandidat: yes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European elections in May 2019 must be held in the most open and democratic way. This means ensuring pluralism in the media of the Member States. Unfortunately in Greece the state media and the majority of private media have imposed a gag regime on our party “Greece - The Other Road”. Although we are a Party represented in the European Parliament, although the speaker is a member of the European Parliament's third member of the European Parliament's political group parliamentary force, Greek media discriminate against us and systematically exclude us from all broadcasts information content. Mr President, we ask the European Parliament and you personally for your support to ensure pluralism in the Greek media and to put an end to the blockade of the ECR and our “Greece - The Other Road” party in the run-up to the 2019 European elections because, otherwise, the elections 2019 in Greece will be a monument of gag and arbitrariness and bias.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Mr President, in recent times Turkey has chosen the path of aggression and provocation in the Aegean and Cyprus, questioning the sovereignty rights of two countries of the European Union. This aggression, among other things, sparks a new wave of military armaments in Greece and Turkey, as evidenced by Eurostat and NATO data, thereby removing significant resources that could be used for the welfare of the two peoples. The European Council reacted to this aggression by Turkey with a politically hypocritical statement in my opinion, in which it simply asks Turkey to stop provocative actions against Greece and Cyprus, and I say politically hypocritical because they are European war industries that continue to sell arms in Turkey, because they earn most of the tension between Greece and Turkey. After all, within the framework of the multiannual financial framework, we are calling for an increase in military spending. The peoples want a peaceful settlement of disputes. On the contrary, it is NATO's imperialist plans and the interests of the European Union's military industry that seek instability... (President interrupted speaker)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, as regards the EU's relations with Turkey, the European Council made another unacceptable mistake. In other words, he proposed that talks should continue with that country. The Heads of State are obviously either indifferent or are not interested in dealing decisively with this international troublemaker, which is endangering security and peace in the Aegean, the Eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East. What further did Turkey have to do in order to be dealt with resolutely by the European Union? To arrest the Italian interests of a research ship and then ask for ransom - European funds - to release it? Did he have to attack in order to occupy the free part of Cyprus, or did he have to create a hot episode with Greece in the Aegean? As long as the European Union tolerates Turkey and does not close its door to its entrance, the more it overestimates its powers and creates problems by being decomposed.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I see a broad consensus between the Commission and a majority of this Parliament, on both the institutional issues and the issue of the Multiannual Financial Framework, so there is no need for me to go into that right now. I need to react briefly to the many comments that were made on the issue of Brexit, especially because of the decision today by the Commission on the draft treaty.  It is fair to say, from my perspective, that Brexit is a decision taken by the British people that needs to be respected by all of us. The right is there of a Member State to decide to leave. At the same time, I shan’t hide the fact that this saddens me greatly, and I also do not want to hide the fact that if they change their minds and want to come back to the European Union, I think we would all welcome them warmly back into the European Union family. I insist on that, because I think there is not one person present in this august forum, including the people up there, who has never changed their minds in their lives. Everybody changes their minds sometimes, and I think that deserves just as much respect as when people decide that they want to go along one course. But I do think there is one responsibility nobody can shy away from, whatever your position is on Brexit, and that is to explain in great detail the consequences of Brexit. That is the reason why the Commission translated the decisions from December into concrete text on concrete issues, and we will be putting it before your Parliament very soon. I also think that those who championed Brexit and are very vocal about that have a responsibility to explain to their constituents why it is going to be such a tremendous success. It is just too easy to then invent a situation which makes it seem as though we were there to punish them. It is not our fault that things are not working out. It is not our fault that you said ‘we are shackled to a corpse’, but now the corpse seems to be doing much better than you are. That is our fault? That is because these Europeans are being so nasty to us. Stop it. Take responsibility for your own position. Explain to your voters what you want from Brexit and then face the consequences if everything you have promised doesn’t work out. We will negotiate in a faithful, honest way, because Brexit will do harm. It will do harm to the UK. It will do harm to Europe, and we have a collective responsibility to make sure that we do as little harm as possible.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — The informal European Council in February dealt with the Multiannual Financial Framework for Turkey and Syria and, of course, Brexit. There is no doubt that we must face the new challenges. But we also need to ensure social and territorial cohesion in the Union, because without a strong cohesion policy there is no unity among European citizens. The European Parliament must also emphasize the opportunity that the European Council risks losing by letting an unavoidable meeting with a European Union better than the current one. The proposal adopted by this Parliament to link the Commission presidency to the top of the list of each of the big political families is a civic, citizen and European culture commitment. Many are also voting in favour of transnational lists, because they mean the beginning of a pan-European response to the need for pan-European citizenship and representation in this European Parliament. In no case can the European Council miss the opportunity to relaunch the European Union and remove it from this state of decline, if not paralysis, in which it has unfortunately been in recent years.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. — (PT) At the last meeting of the European Council on 23 February, the brutal and endless disaster in Syria was discussed, at which we continue to see the loss of human life, the spread of terror, misery and misery. The Council called for the immediate implementation of a ceasefire. Fortunately, that ceasefire has been decreed, even though there have been violations of the ceasefire in the meantime. This is a first step, but we must not forget that this first step has already been taken in the past, without having produced the conditions for establishing a lasting peace. The European Union and its Member States must act uncompromising and without excluding from the outset the use of stronger forms of intervention, if it is necessary to resort to this tragedy, which harvests lives, destroys a country and shames humanity once and for all.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Regarding the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), Romania has confirmed that Member States need to increase their contributions to the EU budget in order to enhance the Union’s capacities to deal with new realities in an efficient manner. Facing the numerous security challenges arising from the south and east, reinforcing border management through the European Border and Coast Guard Agency and showing European solidarity with Africa represent new engagements that require new capital. Furthermore, I would like to stress that, in the new EU27 format, the budgetary gap caused by Brexit should not under any circumstances be filled by resources from our European fundamental policies such as the cohesion fund or the common agriculture policy (CAP), given the alarming effects that scenario could produce on our societies. Therefore, I salute the decisions of the Member States that have already expressed their agreement on an increased budgetary contribution, and I would remind the ones that have not done so that the European project brings to each of us incomparably more gains than our expenditure. I will end by making a comparison: while the EU’s annual budget is below 1% of Europe’s GDP, the federal budget of the United States is equivalent to 30% of its GDP.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — The informal European Council in February dealt with the Multiannual Financial Framework for Turkey and Syria and, of course, Brexit. There is no doubt that we must face the new challenges. But we also need to ensure social and territorial cohesion in the Union, because without a strong cohesion policy there is no unity among European citizens. The European Parliament must also emphasize the opportunity that the European Council risks losing by letting an unavoidable meeting with a European Union better than the current one. The proposal adopted by this Parliament to link the Commission presidency to the top of the list of each of the big political families is a civic, citizen and European culture commitment. Many are also voting in favour of transnational lists, because they mean the beginning of a pan-European response to the need for pan-European citizenship and representation in this European Parliament. In no case can the European Council miss the opportunity to relaunch the European Union and remove it from this state of decline, if not paralysis, in which it has unfortunately been in recent years.
