For the many small and medium-sized distilleries, the system of geographical indication is being simplified and, from the consumer's point of view, we are creating more transparency, for example, through clear rules on rounding sugar.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this file. It may be a technical file, but we do have a duty as elected representatives to protect citizens and their health. I am fully aware that the spirits drinks industry is due to present a self—regulatory proposal for nutritional information, but it is because of this, rather than in spite of this, that I am proposing the two amendments to include the nutritional declarations on spirit drinks and allow for other voluntary nutritional information on the labelling. Any sort of self—regulating proposal will not suffice when it comes to providing citizens with clear information on the products that they buy, and we have an opportunity now to fulfil that.  Consumers’ rights to information should prevail over business interests. The Commission’s report in this matter from March last year identified a knowledge deficit for consumers regarding nutritional information on alcoholic beverages. It also found that there were no grounds to exempt spirit drinks from the Food Information to Consumers Regulation and identified a clear desire among consumers for this information. I would also echo the calls of my colleagues to reject the use of beer alcohol in the production of spirit drinks.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, so-called spirit drinks, therefore spirits and spirits, enjoy a different regulatory regime. This is right, because of the peculiarity of these supply chains; however, this specialty must be linked to high quality standards that must always be guaranteed. Many producers in this sector — often small and medium-sized enterprises — are characterized by traditional production methods, for the use of the highest quality raw materials, for strict controls to protection of the health of the consumer. For these virtuous manufacturers aiming for quality products, we have a duty to provide clear standards and effective measures to combat counterfeiting, and this even more so when we talk about DOP products or PGI, then with geographical indication. In fact, we find on the market products altered to lucrate and drinks that exploit the notoriety of established names without having the requirements, thus misleading consumers. What the Union must do is to put a brake on these illegal practices in a clear and firm voice.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, as one who’s off all alcohol for Lent, I can’t claim to be in high spirits as we discuss these spirits files, but it was a pleasure for me to work on this file on behalf of the PPE/INTA with Pilar Ayuso, Nicola Danti and others. As Commissioner Hogan has pointed out, the Commission’s proposal was put forward to align EU legislation on spirit drinks with the Lisbon Treaty. In addition, it was supposed to contain minor technical adjustments and replace the existing procedures for the management of geographical indications in the spirit drinks sector with new procedures modelled on the more exhaustive and well tested procedures for agricultural products and foodstuffs. Pilar Ayuso and her team have done great work on this legislation. It is not easy to satisfy all Member States, and the work is ongoing, as the Commissioner pointed out. Ireland was satisfied with Regulation 110/2008, and in general did not expect or see the need for a wide ranging discussion on, or reinterpretation of, the spirits regulation that this realignment exercise has turned into. There are a few issues that affect my own country of Ireland, and these would need to be discussed further, such as the system of aging or the issue of Article 8.5 and flavouring, among others. I hope that the trilogues will be able to sort these out to everybody’s satisfaction. Finally, in my country a few years ago there were only four distilleries; now there are 18. This indicates the growth in exports for these wonderful products. I know that Commissioner Hogan has done tremendous work, especially in the Asean countries, to grow agricultural exports in spirits and others as well.

name: Pavel POC
text: — I congratulate my colleague Pilar Ayus and the shadow rapporteurs on the result, because in many respects the text presented is more clear and consistent than the text of the current regulation. I am satisfied that the maximum amount of sugar and sweetening substances by which spirits can be attained is established, because the maximum sugar content was not established in the original Regulation and is clearly significant improvement. From the point of view of my country, I am particularly satisfied that it managed to maintain the exemption from the production of slivovice, since the prunes produced in the Czech Republic using the addition of alcohol remained in the draft regulation in the same wording as in the existing one, which is clearly the right decision. I would recommend voting against amendments 27, 28. We take the view that the status quo applies in the area of the possibility of using alcohol from beer into alcoholic beverages and spirits, i.e. not spreading the raw materials from which alcohol can be produced is better.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would just like to comment briefly on the question of the addition of alcohol from beer to spirits. Of course, ethanol, which comes from the processing of non-alcoholic beer, is also ethanol. Exactly how ethanol can be produced from the by-products of winemaking, from sugar beet, from corn and many other things. That's not the point. The point is that decades ago this small competitive advantage was created for the by-products of winemaking, that these products can be added to spirits, while the by-product from beer production, which, admittedly, has only appeared in recent years — since we have been in non-alcoholic beer — stop is a waste product and does not have this advantage. I think we should think carefully about whether, without any knowledge of what quantities we are talking about here and what is coming for us, we are now simply throwing it overboard, whether we should give this waste product — because it is a waste product in beer production at the end — and allow this additional refinement should be that it can be added to spirits. In any case, in the vote tomorrow, I will advocate that we maintain today's status quo, so that the production of spirits will continue to give preference to those products that come precisely from the distillation of by-products of wine production.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: — Mr President, punishable and credible information on the content and enhancement of traditional practices and territories of origin are two key components in ensuring that the European Union meets its objectives of transparency and identity in the field of spirits. It is also essential to value the historical, cultural and economic dimension associated with traditional production methods, defending designations of origin, ensuring their reliability and protecting the practices associated with the differentiation of high quality products. It is very important to ensure, in particular, that in the context of the dynamic ageing of brandies, the specific formula adopted in committee is respected. In a framework of massive global trade in spirit drinks, the European Union must set an example because, by setting this example, it guarantees consumers relevant information to make their purchasing choices and improves their ability to compete in commercial terms.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Mr. President, first I want to thank Mrs. Ayuso Pilar and congratulations on this file. I understand that this is a technical file and it's about coming into line with the new laws and aligning it with the Lisbon Agreement. I believe that this report is an excellent basis for further negotiations, making sure that we have 8% of exports from this sector and that 10 billion euros are spinning in this sector, this is a very important file, and I am particularly interested in products with protected origin, but also the geographical designation system. The traditional production of alcohol needs to be taken into account and I hope that the Commission will also take this into account. What is important is the new online register, too, an additional list of protected products and protection of products from counterfeiting. That's what I'd put an accent on. For me this is an occasion to mention Dubrovnik Malvasia, a special wine from the Dubrovnik region that has been produced since the time of the Dubrovnik Republic and mentioned in the old Dubrovnik Statute and I hope that this is an opportunity to discuss and include this product on the additional list of products protected Origin. I think we will find an agreement, agree between the Commission and Parliament and that Parliament will retain the role it has so far played. So, I support everything that the ENVI board has so far concluded.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: — Dear friends, Commissioner, this text on alcoholic beverages, on spirits, their use, their names and also on the protection of geographical names is very technical, but I am glad that we have all come to a good result constructively. There is also a significant change that the legal basis will be changed for the current regulation in the future. This legislative text also has a significant impact on agriculture because ethyl alcohol used for the production of spirits must be of agricultural origin. It's a big export commodity. The European Union exports ten billion annually, it is such a flagship of the European Union. Quality alcohol is exported abroad, including Slovak alcohols borovičky, slivovice, and I believe that these geographical names, which we also have in Slovakia, as well as negotiated in this text, will continue to be preserved and respected in the new text. I am also very satisfied that the maximum sugar content in the production of spirits has been established, and this is only correct.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — After 10 years, we have a new regulation on the table that relates to spirits, and I appreciate the changes that bring about simplification of the rules. I consider it right that ethyl alcohol, which arises in the production of non-alcoholic beer, can also be used in the production of spirits. The rules need to be adapted to the new reality, and this is also higher production of non-alcoholic beer. There is no substantive reason why manufacturers should be limited in how to load residual ethyl alcohol. That is why, unlike some colleagues, I support amendments that will allow it to be used. Exports could also threaten a change in the language regime, which would restrict the use of the geographical indication for third countries, for export in the language of those third countries. So I will also support the amendment in this area and the protection of the traditional recipe for manufacturers and consumers should also apply. In the Czech Republic, it is positive that conditions will not change in the conditions for the slivovice.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Mr President, I would like to join in congratulating the rapporteur, Pilar Ayuso, and the entire team of shadow rapporteurs, because I believe that there has been a wonderful proposal for the trialogue negotiation process. I think that a great deal of updating has been done and that all local needs and varieties have been met. I would especially like to thank the work that has been done with the incorporation of the model applied to a well-known spirit drink, such as the brandy de Jerez, a model in which, in terms of rounding the final flavor of the product, natural sweet wine is usually used. This rounding is called “solera y crianza” and is something very traditional enshrined in national legislation. This is reflected in the proposal — which I am delighted — as well as other traditional varieties and methods, and I welcome that. I would also like to refer to the amendments on nutritional profiles. I am not against it; I am against the amendments: this is not the place. The labelling regulation must be awaited and appropriate contributions should be made there.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, with an annual trade surplus of around EUR 10 billion, or 8% of total European agri-food exports, the spirit drinks sector is one of the most important sectors in this field and generates around 1 million jobs. Until now, Regulation (EC) No 110/2008 established a regulatory framework for these spirit drinks, which generally satisfies professionals in the sector. It is therefore the overall modernization of this legislation that is at the centre of our concern. I am pleased that Article 43 (2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union has been introduced as a legal basis, thus providing agricultural anchoring to this legislation. Spirituous drinks represent an important market for agricultural production in the European Union, whether in qualitative or quantitative terms. By the way, alcohol used in the production of spirit drinks must be of agricultural origin. I conclude by saying that it is crucial that consumers can legitimately be confident that within the Union any drink labelled such as vodka, whiskey or rum is the product they expect.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, geographical indications and the designation of origin of alcoholic beverages are intangible collective goods which need to be protected by the European Union because they contribute to development. This is particularly true, Mr Hogan, for Greece, which produces many traditional drinks, such as tsikoudia, tsipouro and ouzo. The protection of geographical indications for alcoholic beverages is constantly jeopardised by international trade liberalisation agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, such as CETA. Moreover, despite the pressure of the Commission, Greece should not abolish the reduced excise duty on national traditional drinks such as raki and tsipouro, because the European Union must finally protect small producers of raki and tsipouro and not the multinationals of whiskey and gin. So withdraw the action against Greece to the Court of Justice of the European Union!

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is important for consumers in the European Union to find on labels the ingredients and nutritional information that are part of all alcoholic beverages, and this is necessary to ensure a level high consumer protection, but also to ensure the prevention of fraudulent practices, as well as market transparency and fair competition. That is why it is beneficial for both industry and consumers to have a regulatory proposal at Union level as soon as possible aimed at providing information on the ingredients and nutritional content of alcoholic beverages. Such measures will be able to help protect the reputation that Union produced spirit drinks have acquired on the world market, respecting traditional practices used in the production process of spirit drinks. I consider it important that technological innovation occupies an important place in this sector in a context where it can contribute to improving quality without affecting the traditional nature of the spirits in question.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, spirit drinks are among the products covered by the EU protective scheme based on geographical indication. It is important to have rules concerning the protection of these products and to have regulations for making management procedures for spirit drinks more homogeneous. Therefore, I support the modification of geographical indications, as the different schemes for geographical indications in the European Union need to be harmonised, taking into consideration, however, the specificities of the spirit drinks sector of each and every Member State.  I welcome any action which would lead to increased consumer protection and stronger protection of consumer interests. It is of great importance that consumers, when buying anything labelled as vodka, whisky or pálinka on the EU market, have confidence that they will receive exactly what they expect – the original product and not a fake – and unfortunately there are still lots of fake products on the market.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the proposal for a regulation on alcoholic beverages has some flaws. Firstly, it does not comply with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality and does not take into account that, because of the nature of spirit drinks, geographical indications of such products must be protected. If there is a question of waiving this protection, this should be an initiative of the Member State and not of the Commission. In addition, the bottling and packaging of spirit drinks must be carried out within the geographical area concerned in order to protect their quality and specific characteristics. Otherwise, there is a risk that these will be distorted and that the consumer will not be protected. Finally, in Greece the production of traditional alcoholic beverages, such as ouzo, tsikoudia and tsipouro, must be protected because the producers of these products have small family businesses and, if this protection is lifted, they will suffer economic destruction.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this evening’s debate. There is a clear acknowledgment of the importance of the spirit drinks sector across the European Union, and I agree with Ms Ribeiro’s and Mr Kelly’s assessment that the work undertaken by the rapporteur and Parliament as a whole is a good basis for taking the negotiations forward and into the trialogues. Mr Marias knows very well that the Commission has achieved geographical indications protection for many Greek products where it was difficult to achieve, particularly in relation to free trade agreements such as CETA and SADC and with Vietnam and Japan. We will do so again in negotiations that are ongoing. It seems to me that there are a relatively small number of political issues which need to be resolved, though I would recall the reservations that I mentioned in my opening remarks, particularly around empowerments. Other issues were mentioned here this evening as well, one of which Ms Boylan and Ms Aguilera García mentioned, which was around nutrition labelling. I hope that, following the plenary vote, the Council will move quickly to adopt its mandate in order to allow us to start trialogues. I am confident that together we can reach an agreement that meets most people’s concerns and continues to support the strong European spirits and drinks sector, which, as Mr Tarabella mentioned, is worth EUR 10 billion and one million jobs in the European Union.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, thank you very much to all those who have spoken. I understand that this is a good report, with everyone's help, with everyone's amendments, and that it is true that we have an important underlying problem — basically we agree on everything — which is the problem of beer alcohol. There are arguments for and arguments against, and they are all valid. But I am aware that alcohol from Annex II plant products has always been used for this type of beverage, and beer is not a Annex II product, although it is true that beer alcohol has its origin in plant products. In any case, we will see what happens in the vote tomorrow. Finally, what I would like is to request your support in order to obtain a mandate so that we can begin negotiations with the Council. I hope that with the help of the shadow rapporteurs, the Council and the Commission, we will be able to achieve a good regulation, at the level of what we currently have, which will protect such an important sector — as has been said here — as is the spirits sector.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 March 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: in writing. — I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for this report on the great work she has done. In my view, we are dealing with a good report in general terms which includes basic issues such as the need to make clear the important link of this sector with agriculture and the agri-food legislative framework. This is an extremely linked sector to traditional know-how in many European regions, and this is something that the report makes clear. As a result, it is necessary that the different national laws, drafted with better knowledge of each national and regional reality, must be respected by European legislation. As a Spanish MEP, one of my biggest concerns was the recognition by European legislation of ageing methods applied in brandy production. I am glad to know that this has indeed been taken up after the vote in the Committee on the Environment and that the labelling references to the 'criaderas and solera' system will be accepted.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Frank Engel, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2016 (2017/2125(INI)) (A8—0025/2018).

name: Frank ENGEL
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as we begin this debate tonight, we are still in the shock of the assassination of a second journalist in the European Union in a few months. These cowardly and abject assassinations show us that in the European Union people are determined to radically question freedom of expression — one of the many civil liberties, one of the many fundamental rights we have. These assassinations show us how urgent it is to maintain the day before for fundamental rights, for the right of expression, for our freedom of all, for the freedom of those who investigate and reveal facts which, of course, are not pleasing to all but which must be revealed to the general public because they have the right to know. Mr President, in the preparation of this report, we have reached — and I welcome it — an almost ecumenical agreement in this House — at least between its reasonable and constructive parties. We managed to cover the entire land that was to be covered, with 44 major compromise amendments. However, we still focused on a few major themes. I had proposed two at the beginning: the rule of law and the phenomenon of migration, in all its variations and also in its interaction with the rule of law, because the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights are the basis of European integration. A democratic community is not built on bases other than the predictability of the State, the reason for its action, the absence of arbitrariness and the guarantee of the rights that citizens have acquired over the centuries. The Copenhagen criteria exist, but subsequently they no longer exist too much, we discussed them again this afternoon in this House in the context of the activation of Article 7 against the Poland. It is clear that we need instruments that will enable us in the future to achieve a European logic of governance in which we all agree on what is acceptable and what is not, what an election can serve and what it cannot be used for. It should not be used to fundamentally change the nature of a State. It must change policies, policies which must be able to change once again after the next election, without questioning the nature of the state between them. In order to achieve this European logic of governance, Parliament has already suggested, in a resolution adopted on 25 October 2016, the establishment of a European mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. We have asked the Commission to endorse the ideas contained in this report. I think I understood from Commissioner Timmermans a while ago that he wants to do this, and I think it is commendable. On the issue of migration, Mr President, we know that it will continue and that it is better for us to get used to designing accompanying policies instead of acting as if we are going to stop migration. Migration does not stop, they have never stopped over the course of history. We need to invent legal avenues for migration, including in the absence of conflicts. There is a need to improve the reception of migrants, especially minors and children, and there is a need to invest heavily in training, education and intercultural dialogue. I will pass on to you the other elements of the report, Mr President, firstly because my time is coming to an end, secondly because all this is recorded in writing. I welcome the debate we are going to have and I will have the opportunity to come back to it again afterwards.

name: Věra Jourová
text: členka Komise. – Nejdříve mi dovolte pozdravit naše krajany, kteří jsou podle mých informací na balkóně, dobrý večer, pěkně zdravím. Yes, I am a politician after several years. But to be serious, for this is a very serious topic that we are going to discuss here today. First of all, let me start my contribution by strongly condemning the shocking murder of two innocent young people, one of whom was a brave journalist. This is not only an attack on people, it is an attack on freedom of speech and on democracy and our values, and I strongly believe that the Slovak authorities, maybe in cooperation with the European agencies, Europol and Eurojust, will find and punish the perpetrators so that we can see that justice works and justice lives in Slovakia and in the European Union. Now let me come back to the report and start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Engel, for drafting it. This is a very comprehensive report which touches upon a number of issues that are very relevant to the current context.  First, let me highlight the crucial importance of upholding EU values, including the rule of law and the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I assure you that the Commission is using all the means at its disposal to promote and uphold the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. This includes the application of the rule of law framework and the launching of infringement proceedings when needed, as well as triggering the mechanisms of Article 7 of the Treaty where  necessary. In line with its communication on the enforcement of EU law, the Commission has started to pursue a strategic approach with regard to infringement proceedings, in particular when respect for the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights is at stake. The Commission has initiated infringement proceedings to fight a key challenge, the segregation of Roma children in education, which is explicitly raised in the report. The Commission has mobilised and aligned its targeted and mainstreamed policy and funding instruments to promote inclusive reforms of public policies. On the rule of law, as announced in 2018 work programme, the Commission will, towards the end of this year, present an initiative to strengthen its enforcement within the EU.  Secondly, you have raised the issue of the shrinking space for civil society in Europe. Within the last month the Commission has strongly affirmed the importance it attaches to the existence of a vibrant and free civil society and to regular and transparent engagement with civil society. We are monitoring developments at national level and will not hesitate to act when measures are taken in violation of Member States’ obligations under the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights – just as we did in Hungary’s case in December 2017, when we initiated proceedings in the Court of Justice concerning the Hungarian law on foreign-funded NGOs. We are also considering how to further support and empower civil society actors to help them perform their role and build resilience, encompassing that subject within the broader discussion on the next multiannual financial framework.  Thirdly and finally, the report very much underlines the need to take action against racism, intolerance, disinformation and toxic narratives, which are shrinking the space for well-informed democratic discussions in the public sphere and polarising our societies. We could not agree more. The Commission is leading the work on countering the increasingly worrying phenomenon of illegal online hate speech. Just this morning we have adopted a recommendation on measures to effectively tackle illegal content online. In this proposal we strike the right balance between the need to take effective measures against illegal content and ensuring that we can address the special challenges of terrorism content without stifling innovation or the exploitation of business opportunities offered in the online world.  The recommendation recognises that the need for measures may vary depending on the types of illegal content and combines the need for effective notice and action procedures with strong safeguards on over-removal and caution in areas where contextualisation is needed to determine the illegality of content when automatised means of detection are used without human intervention. The particular needs and urgencies relate to tackling terrorist content.  The recommendation sends a strong signal to industry on our expectations and keeps up pressure through the possibility of regulatory action. We are continuing to work intensively with Member States and civil society to step up the implementation of EU law on the ground, combat racism and xenophobia and ensure that prompt investigation, prosecution and proportionate punishment become a reality in Member States. The fight against intolerance starts with civil education and a deeper understanding by public authorities and institutions of the reasons behind this engagement of citizens with values. This year we are particularly supporting initiatives to re-engage citizens in the EU democratic process, not least in anticipation of the 2019 European elections, and we need to work together on this endeavour.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Looks like the Czechs have a majority in the boardroom for once.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, thanks are to my colleague Frank Engel for drafting this report. Nevertheless, I have some reservations about this report and they relate to three headings: institutional, migration and gender issues. Firstly, if a Member State systematically violates fundamental rights and weakens the rule of law, it is the Commission's duty to refer to the European Court of Justice. The introduction of a new European administrative-policy mechanism will not solve anything. Secondly, the issue of migration and asylum is a very serious and complex problem. All the more we should always make a clear distinction between refugees and illegal migrants. Otherwise, we will come to the conclusion that we will begin to question the right of the Member States to decide who, and under what circumstances and conditions, can enter and reside in their own territory. Finally, there is a group of proposals on sexuality, gender, marriage and reproductive health. I have serious reservations about a number of paragraphs, but I will mention only one: it is a call for political influence on medical practices and standards. This is unacceptable to me as a doctor — the Commission, governments or Members simply do not dictate medical science what it should consider as a disease and what is not.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mr Engel, with whom we have carried out this work. We started this session by remembering the Slovak journalist brutally murdered yesterday, as well as all the victims of inquiry journalism. We stood up, aware that freedoms of expression, information and the media are key to ensuring democracy and the rule of law. Our societies cannot develop without a free, independent, accountable media system based on principles such as fact-checking, measures to limit fake news, protection of sources and the safety of journalists. We strongly condemn any form of incitement to hatred, including the increasingly frequent statements, by political leaders and parties, of racist and xenophobic political ideas and discourse. In the resolution we recall the inherent link between the rule of law and fundamental rights. We bluntly condemn all kinds of discrimination based on sex, race, skin colour, ethnic and social origin and sexual orientation. We call on the Commission to appoint coordinators for Afrophobia and Anti-Ziganism and to strengthen the fight against forms of racism and discrimination towards Afro-descendants and Roma. We found that migrants and refugees are increasingly victims of acts of discrimination and violence and the subject of closure policies by other Member States. Finally, we call in full voice for solidarity and respect for the fundamental rights of migrants seeking asylum, but above all, in the field of migration, that safe and legal channels to Europe be soon strengthened.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, although I have read this report, of course, I see the broad work of a colleague on it, but I have yet to get the impression that Europe is a kind of continent of fear that is dominated by phobias. Xenophobia, transphobia, Islamophobia, intersexphobia, homophobia, aphrophobia are mentioned here. Fear of all layers, races and group identities. Disproportionately, the group of homophobes grows with those who have a different view of the way they coexist between people, between men and women. I observe the phenomenon that people are beginning to be afraid to publicly say their opinion on the introduction of new sociological and value frameworks. So where was the right to disagree lost? This is our fundamental right to express dissent, and that disagreement as a difference of opinion must be respected. Why are those with a different opinion immediately sticked as fanatics, populists, fundamentalists, bigots? Europe should not be afraid of diversity, especially not the opinion. I consider reiterating calls for Member States to ratify the controversial Istanbul Convention in this report to be an inappropriate and further violation of the principle of subsidiarity. A third of the states Istanbul Convention... (The President took the floor from the speaker)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I wholeheartedly welcome the report as it addresses key challenges in the area of fundamental rights and also addresses the recent worrying developments in certain Member States. I would like to congratulate Mr Engel on a very comprehensive text which is also very timely. Some colleagues have already mentioned the recent attacks on freedom of speech. The assassination of journalists is an absolute disaster, a tragedy beyond words, and my heart reaches out to the people suffering now from the sorrow of the loss. Rule of law, democracy and respect for fundamental rights must always be upheld, because they are the principles and values upon which the European Union was founded. I would just like to mention that the Common European Asylum System needs to be addressed. We are lacking this in the Union at this moment and we need to ensure that a resilient system is built, based on the participation of all Member States and the fair sharing of responsibilities, as is mentioned in the report. It is imperative that the rule of law also prevails in respect of those seeking asylum in our Union. We have all ratified the Geneva Convention, so it goes without saying that this is imperative. It is also imperative to defend and protect values and principles and to take action in any case of breaches of these values.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, the protection of fundamental rights must be a priority for the European Union, both internally and in its external relations. The contraction of rights, which is observed in critical areas such as social rights, does not allow any complacency. The report we are debating today does not sufficiently emphasise the deficiencies in the protection of fundamental rights in practice. It is characteristic that no reference is made to the impact of the implementation of budgetary adjustment programmes on the fundamental rights of millions of citizens of the Union, such as labour rights and health, nor to the consequences of environmental degradation. Similarly, the systematic violation of fundamental rights in candidate countries such as Turkey is obscure. We need universal protection and not selective protection, with effective actions and not wishful thinking.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, We live at a time when our fundamental freedoms and rights are being challenged in Europe. In the spirit of collective fear of terrorism and migrants, the sense of nationalism and undemocratic forces is strengthened. Everything is worth sacrificing on the altar of fear, and particularly vulnerable are minorities in different countries. But that's not enough. States in the EU legislate whether, or otherwise act for, to curtail freedom of expression and/or press, limit the independence of the courts and/or allow corruption to drain common resources without punishing the culprits. In principle, the EU can do nothing. Since several months back, former EU parliamentarian Oriol Junqueras is in custody along with three others in Spain, accused of, among other things, rebellion and sedition during the disputed October 2017 referendum in Catalonia, despite no force being used from the Catalan page. The Spanish court argues that they should have understood that the Spanish police would use force; therefore they are guilty. When two fundamental EU values stand against each other, it must not mean that the importance of following one narrows the other.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Mr President, Mr Engel's report is a summary of the double language of hypocrisy usually practiced by the majority of this Parliament to the detriment of the peoples it would have to protect. This staggering text, but which comes after many others, does not address, for example, the situation of whistleblowers — like Julian Assange, who is still threatened with arrest in London, like Edward Snowden, who has found refuge, ladies and gentlemen, only in Moscow — nor the situation of Europeans who become foreigners every day in their own country, or the restrictions on freedom of expression, in history, in morals, in politics, which have multiplied by memory laws, which are worth us in Europe hundreds of state persecution, prosecution, criminal convictions — including prison sentences. No! It refers only to the complaints of indigenous people who become foreigners every day in their own country and who are victims of delinquency. In fact, it is a hate speech that is about, but it is in the report, it is hatred of European identity. It is the hatred of everything we should defend... (the President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I appreciate the fact that the report raises the situation of autochthonous national minorities in the EU. While the protection of minorities is a basic value of the European Union and an essential part of the Copenhagen criteria, there are still no common standards for minority protection in the EU. Relegating this competence to the national sphere means that the situation of such minorities varies extremely in our shared area of freedom, security and justice from almost full equality to denied existence. The initial hopes of minorities in newly acceded Member States gave way to disappointment. Post-accession practice showed that once their country became an EU Member State, there were no EU legal provisions and there was no political pressure to guarantee their rights. The Fourth Council of Europe Opinion on the application in Romania of the Framework Convention on the Protection of National Minorities, published a week ago, clearly illustrates this unfortunate situation. The expert opinion describes in detail what I have also repeatedly drawn attention to in this House: it expresses serious concerns regarding matters such as hate speech against minorities, difficulties regarding education in students’ mother tongue, the obstruction of the restitution process for properties stolen by the communist regime, the prohibition of the use of national symbols, and so on. It is time that the EU also addressed these matters and no longer allowed the rights of EU citizens to be disrespected.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President! The annual report on the situation of fundamental rights in Europe is an important cornerstone of our work. This year we are dealing with a particularly balanced and forward-looking report. The rapporteur, Mr Engel, and his shadow rapporteurs should be warmly congratulated on this. Particularly noteworthy in this report is the focus on the rule of law, as we are faced with a number of worrying developments in some Member States. In the case of Poland, the Commission has already initiated an Article 7 procedure and, in the case of Hungary, the LIBE Committee is currently examining this link. This is not, of denounding individual countries, but of observing closely whether developments are going in the wrong direction and correcting them at an early stage. We need a low-threshold instrument. I therefore welcome the recommendation to establish a permanent mechanism for democracy and the rule of law.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the report before us is a monument of discrimination against European citizens. The reality is distorted by the selective interpretation of fragmentary data, while an attempt is being made to widen the concepts of discrimination and minorities, directly seeking to break up the social fabric. Furthermore, it is planned to overthrow the current legal order, guided by the destructive policy of open borders, without taking into account the wishes and needs of the Member States. But the Union is obliged to respect the national identity inherent in the fundamental political and constitutional structure. The more multiculturalism and marginalisation of European citizens are promoted, through the forced integration of illegal immigrants, who refuse to share human and Christian values, the more the incidence of terrorism, robbery and rape will increase. The report is a means of disorientation, an enforcement tool and a product of grey propaganda that promotes globalisation and the dissolution of national identity and consciousness.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Mr President, I welcome these annual reports which seek to defend the human rights of all victims, and I therefore find it particularly shocking that, in a report covering 2016, where Europe was wildly punished by terrorism, there is no reference to the victims of terrorism. Twenty-two pages that speak rightly — and which I applaud and support — of women victims of gender-based violence, trafficking, LGBT groups victims of hatred, migrants, and so on. But not a single mention of the victims of terrorism. Or have we forgotten the 2016 attack in Brussels, where thirty-two people lost their lives and much were injured? Or was the Nice attack, where eighty-four people, many of them children, were killed and hundreds injured? And I could continue to cite European cities where terrorists violated the first fundamental rights: the right to life. When the rapporteur cites in his explanatory statement the numerous reports from Parliament which have served as a reference to him, the report on the fight against terrorism, the main objective of which is to guarantee freedom, security and justice for all Europeans, does not appear. I will give my positive vote on this report because for me all victims deserve equal respect, but I would like to state that victims of terrorism need greater support from the European Union in protecting their fundamental rights and in the defence of memory, dignity and justice.

name: Anna HEDH
text: - Mr President! I am pleased that every year we are doing a report on fundamental rights in the EU. For me, it is extremely important to know how the citizens of the European Union are doing. The report lifts many important issues, but usually these reports feel more like fine words on paper. I have been an EU parliamentarian for more than a decade. The same issues have come up every year without there having been any major improvement. For me, it's particularly sad to see how refugee situations have been handled. Here we see that those affected are women and children. It's a disgrace! We are to be ashamed that we do not have a policy of solidarity for refugees. It is also with sadness I see on the EU's equality policy. Many issues have been joyfully lifted over the years on the EU table, such as men's violence against women, but it is going far too slow. All Member States must sign the Istanbul Convention! Moreover, we need to take the fight for an equal society more seriously and work harder. The Commission is going to give us an equality strategy and a human trafficking strategy now. It brings more than we think and puts pressure on member countries. It's 2018 and women are supposed to have the same basic rights as men.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President! Actually, this report missed its subject, because when I read this report, it is a migration report, then it is an integration report. But this is about the fundamental rights of the citizens of the EU. EU citizens today are struggling to preserve their identity — which is also a fundamental right — to preserve their culture and language. They are fighting to have the right to freedom of expression and the right to freedom of information. However, the fact that thousands of Europeans are being persecuted because of their opinion that 1 200 people are imprisoned in Germany alone because they have expressed the wrong opinion, this report does not allow us to talk about it. I can only ask you to take a closer look at reality, because our task is to preserve and preserve the peoples of Europe and not primarily to bring strangers to Europe who do not belong here.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am one of those who believe that Europe cannot be reduced to the economic dimension, to the Single Market. I defend a citizens' Europe, based on fundamental rights and the rule of law. Respect for fundamental rights is one of the criteria for membership of the European Union and we cannot accept that they can be forgotten by the Member States once they enter the Union. This Parliament, as the representative of all European citizens, must be vigilant and uncompromising with those who disregard these rights or fail to protect them. Unfortunately, recent experience confirms the need for more effective mechanisms in monitoring and sanctioning the prevaricating states. In recent years, men and women fleeing war and oppression have arrived on our shores, refugees who, supported by international law, came in search of someone who protected them. Sadly, we weren't up to it either. We are currently living in a situation of discrimination and serious racism that European leaders admit but do not want to face. According to statistics, a large number of Europeans are broken down by their age, gender, colour, orientation or so many other reasons. I regret that every year it has to be remembered that Member States continue to block a directive on something so essential: equality of all before the law. I congratulate the rapporteur, frankly, Frank Engel on his excellent report and for having succeeded in demonstrating that, although the Union is the part of the world that protects fundamental rights the most, there is still a great deal of work to be done.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, this European Parliament is doing well to deal with the fundamental rights protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which cover not only European citizens, but anyone on our territory. And the landscape described is dark, marked by populism, extreme nationalism, hatred of the different, stigmatization of the other and hate speech leading to xenophobia and racism. And that is why I think it is imperative to talk about three urgent challenges. The first is inclusion — migrants and refugees — and solidarity towards those who build walls against those who knock on the gates of Europe. The second is equality: yes, too, women's rights against violence and the reduction, restriction of their sexual and reproductive health rights. Thirdly, the fight against all forms of discrimination, which affects not only the LGBTI group but also, in Europe, the members of the Roma population, Jews who are increasingly anti-Semitism, those who suffer any hate speech and phobia... (the President withdraws the floor).

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr. President, equality is a fundamental right in the European Union. It should be recognised and respected by all the Member States and the European institutions. We are defending it through internal and external actions. Nevertheless, we cannot only discuss equality when it suits us. For example, the report talks about the rule of law and corruption. However, the Commission has shown corruption in the European Union, while the cooperative and verification mechanism for both Romania and Bulgaria has been maintained. It is difficult not to feel a sense of double standards or inequality in the European Union. Let’s talk about equality when it comes to accession to the Schengen area or double standards concerning the composition of food products in different Member States. I strongly believe that equality between all European Union citizens is a fundamental right, regardless of the Member State they come from, and it should be taken more seriously. I look forward to working closely with my colleagues in the European Parliament to defend it in order to ensure that this right will be applied to all European Union citizens without any double standards…  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Mr. President, by building a European project, we should have obtained a common rule of law and free trade space in which civil and religious liberties are respected and in which all citizens are free to be who they are, as long as they respect the laws. Unfortunately, the European project has turned into a powerful tool for imposing worldview views on Member States and their citizens. Instead of pluralism, we get a uniform view of human and minority rights, and anyone who has a different thinking gets labeled as an extremist, hater or even a fascist. If we want a democratic Europe where all citizens will be happy and satisfied, we must stop creating political and worldview monopolies and allow everyone to express themselves freely and live according to their values as long as they do not violate the laws and negatively affect the freedom of other people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, memorandum and austerity policies have increased poverty and unemployment in Greece and have led to a violation of the fundamental rights of Greeks and, in particular, to a violation of their social rights. The memorandum measures deprived the poor Greek people of the right to access basic public goods such as health, education and social security. At the same time, they cut off pensions, violating the right to property. The European Union, and in particular the Commission, must respect the Charter of Fundamental Rights in Greece, but this is not the case, and even Mr K. Mr Moscovici, in response to a question to the Commission on the violation of the European Social Charter and claiming that the European Social Charter is not binding and does not impose legal obligations on the European Union and the Member States. In other words, the European Commission is washing its hands and accepting a violation of the Charter of Social Rights in Greece. She is a member of the troika that violates rights in Greece.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, today freedoms and rights are at stake in Spain. Freedom of speech, freedom of communication, freedom of assembly, the right to choose your own government and the independence of the judiciary have all been violated in Catalonia. Today, four Catalan leaders are being held in custody without trial and without bail. Although they have always been peaceful, they are accused of violent sedition and rebellion. They could be jailed for 30 years. The Catalan President and some Ministers have decided to go into exile in Belgium and Switzerland in order to avoid an unfair trial. Madam Commissioner, for how long will the Commission keep supporting these policies?

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Personally, I fear that this report lacks a fundamental theme. It is, of course, a good thing that we are dedicated to minority issues, but we must not overlook the problems that huge numbers of Europeans, that is, the majority, have. We all know that the majority of the EU people are constantly worried about the financial stability of the family or fear debt, struggle with it and are in the execute. Young couples don't know if they will be able to afford their own family, young families with children don't know if they will ever be able to afford their own housing, workers are worried about the amount of their pension and pensioners vials. These are the topics that we should address and that relate to fundamental human rights. At the end I find it necessary and let me mention the sad news from Slovakia. The deaths of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová must be investigated as soon as possible so that we know the truth about this cowardly and vile act. My condolences to the families of the bereaved.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr. President! Dear Commissioner Jourová, I am very pleased that you put your headset on, because I would like to address you and ask you, in your opinion, as a lawyer, as your colleague, which is the more serious infringement? To beat nearly a thousand people to blood by the police while exercising their right to choose, see Spain, Catalonia, Spanish police, or regulating the functioning of NGOs supported from abroad? I would ask you kindly to point your finger, either an F or a deuce, so that the dear citizens of the European Union make it clear to you which is the major infringement. Would you mind showing me that? I am surprised that he is not willing to take this, because in his opening speech he spoke about the Hungarian “violation”, not about Catalan. It is now time to stop not only transphobia, homophobia, xenophobia, but also Hungarian phobia, Hungarophobia. We've had enough, stop now... (The President has withdrawn the floor)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me conclude on behalf of the Commission by reiterating two basic principles which I mentioned in my opening speech. Fundamental rights in the EU belong to all citizens, not only to parts of the societies, and we have a duty to guarantee this in all Member States. We speak about equality in front of the law, and it applies to everybody.  The second principle. The European Commission is a very strong defender of the freedom of expression, and we show this very clearly in our activity and initiative in relation to online hate speech, where we work with the IT sector in a very careful way and where we always emphasise that freedom of expression is untouchable unless there are calls for violence, which are prohibited by criminal law in all the Member States.  So these are the principles which I wanted to remind you of in this place. The last comment concerns what I heard here in on Istanbul convention. I am convinced that we are not breaching the principle of subsidiarity. The convention has been signed by all Member States. Slovakia, if I’m not mistaken, signed the Istanbul Convention in 2011. Now we are in the process of ratification, and yes, I confirm here that I invest a lot in convincing the Member States to ratify this very useful piece of legislation.  Let me remind you of the horrifying statistics we have in the EU. Every third woman has experienced physical violence in the last five years, and I ask all of you how big this statistic must be to start acting at the legislative level? The Istanbul Convention is a very important legislative contribution to enable the Member States to investigate, prosecute and penalise the perpetrators of violence against women, and I want to emphasise that the convention can be an efficient instrument against such horrible phenomena as forced abortion, forced marriage and female genital mutilation, to mention some of the horrible forms of violence. However, it also addresses the traditional – and I use this word intentionally – forms of violence. Tradition is a very important element in our society, but there are things which we should get rid of, and I am very much convinced that it is violence against women which we have to combat and get rid of in our societies. All actors have a role to play to renew our commitment to fundamental rights, rule of law and democracy, be it at national, European or international level, and we are fully committed to play ours.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, as it is late, I will not delay the work of the House any longer. I once again wanted to thank the shadow rapporteurs with whom I have been able to work on this report and with whom it was possible to produce an overall work that I find quite presentable. I thank the Commissioner for this convergent approach that we have between the Commission and the European Parliament in this area and in many others. I would like to answer one or another colleague who seems to be concerned about the absence of certain subjects that this may be due to two factors: to the orientations of the rapporteur or his colleagues at the beginning or, too, to the total absence of proposed amendments because, together with colleagues, I made myself a point of honour to incorporate every major point of a concern that would have been submitted by a colleague. If something is not contained in the text, it is because nobody proposed it. Finally, I could still engage in a lengthy epic debate with Mr Gollnisch on European identity, but I am not going to raise the historic channel of the National Front in this way. Therefore, I just wanted to tell him and all his fellow men that everything that is excessive is insignificant.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 1 March 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - This report on human rights in the EU in 2016 focuses considerable attention on women's rights and gender equality issues. First of all, it must be increasingly recalled that women and children are at greater risk of becoming victims of trafficking, being exploited and experiencing sexual abuse, and child protection systems must be developed and strengthened to prevent violence against children, violence against children them, their disregard and exploitation. We strongly condemn the increased trafficking in human beings, whose executors must be responsible for their actions and stand before the court. Member States should also cooperate more closely and intensify the fight not only against organised crime, including trafficking and trafficking in human beings, but also against exploitation, forced labour, sexual exploitation and torture, while protecting victims. Secondly, we still do not solve the big problem of gender inequality, namely the pay gap between women and men, which amounts to more than 16%, which has a negative impact on women's pensions, which is 40% lower than men. Therefore, women in old age are exposed to a greater threat of poverty and exclusion. We therefore call on Member States to develop appropriate policies to support older women and to address the structural causes of gender pay differences. Finally, we must continue to call on the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention, because we must fight violence against women, and so far they have not yet ratified more than one third of all EU countries.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — The basis of European integration lies in respecting and promoting human rights, democracy and the rule of law. For this reason in the world, European states are perceived as a bulwark for the protection of individual freedoms. However, despite recent reports from international and European agencies and organisations reporting significant progress, there are still violations of fundamental rights. Increasing cases of minority discrimination and incitement to racial hatred. The situation is alarming. Protecting the human rights of the most vulnerable groups deserves special attention. Whoever flees from wars and despair must be received in a proper and dignified way. However, I would like to point out a fact that strangely no report on fundamental rights will ever contain. Since the onset of frost these days in Europe about 20 people have died who lived in conditions of destitute. If fundamental rights include the protection of the dignity of the human person, moral and legal equality and the right to health, these things cannot happen in Europe.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The report on the situation of fundamental rights is an opportunity to assess every year how the EU and its Member States perform in this important area. The topics listed may also be given by the data, experience and current issues collected in the given year, but this Parliament Status Report should also adhere to a certain permanent examination framework. This year's report has taken a direction and focuses on topics that are difficult for me to identify. However, it lacks, or at least a marginal discussion of the rights and situation of indigenous minorities, which account for 10% of EU residents. This is why it is important that, one month earlier, on 7 February, Parliament adopted a resolution entitled Protecting and combating discrimination against minorities in EU Member States, which deals specifically with indigenous minorities and discriminatory against them eradication of treatment in the EU. The latter opens a new chapter on the steps taken to protect indigenous minorities and can also guide the relevant European Parliament committees and other EU institutions in future work.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The Annual Fundamental Rights Report states that there is no common definition of the rule of law and the fundamental values of the European Union, but it calls on Member States, urges the application of the Article 7 procedure and calls for the establishment of the rule of law mechanism. This is in itself a contradiction and thus puts the perception of certain Member States on a political path. In my view, the Fundamental Rights Report, in its present form, contributes to measuring the rule of law according to the position taken by a Member State on migration, and this is totally unacceptable. It also concerns a number of areas that clearly fall within the competence of the Member States and therefore have nothing to look for in a similar report.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. - Annual reports show an increasingly less favourable picture of human rights, fundamental rights and the rule of law in the European Union. There is no substantial improvement in relation to the largest European minority, the Roma. There are still many unacceptable discrimination between LGBGT people almost everywhere in Europe. Rough human rights violations by authorities are also common among refugee seekers. However, the most worrying phenomenon is the gradual narrowing of civil society's room for manoeuvre. The developments that take place in Hungary are particularly scandalous. Where the government's “Stop Soros” bill seeks to block civil society with the most harsh means, especially refugee support organisations. The Hungarian government considers refugees and, consequently, the organisations assisting them as national security risks. Therefore, they are subject to a separate permit by the Minister of Internal Affairs, imposes a special tax on financial assistance from abroad, and even intends to monitor them by means of intelligence services. The European Parliament has a fundamental duty to protect NGOs, without which there is no democracy. We need to stand up for them and create a Democracy Fund to support these NGOs directly and in the long term. We must strongly reject all political initiatives aimed at restricting or preventing civil society from working for beneath political reasons.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. — I must note that the 2016 annual own-initiative report on fundamental rights in the EU (as in the other years) focuses on the rule of law, migration, integration and discrimination and not on all aspects of rights fundamental in the EU. Although the EU is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. It is true that the inflow of migrants and asylum seekers continued to Europe in 2016, with racist and xenophobic reactions against them being widespread and vulnerable populations continuing to face high levels of discrimination and violence. However, we believe that we must fight for the principles of equality and justice throughout the EU, by not accepting in any way the violations of fundamental human rights, which continue in some Member States, and no discrimination against any European citizen or threats to address of the rule of law. Of course, Member States have the ultimate responsibility to protect human rights by ratifying and applying international human rights treaties and conventions.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Council and Commission Declarations on the work and legacy of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (2018/2530 (RSP)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia was established by the UN Security Council in 1993 to deal with war crimes committed during the conflicts in the Western Balkans in the 1990s. The European Union has consistently supported the work of the Tribunal. Human rights violations and war crimes – whether in the past or in the present – have to be addressed. The Tribunal carried out important work and contributed to ending a prevalent sense of impunity, hence contributing to peace as well as fostering reconciliation and strengthening the rule of law. The Tribunal also contributed to the development of international law and legal praxis. It built up an extensive jurisprudence in international criminal law. The EU commends these developments that will contribute to future work in the area of international justice. The EU has always underlined the need to address impunity and ensure accountability, as well as to fully cooperate with and support the work of the Tribunal. We condemn any attempt to minimise or deny war crimes and genocide. Over the years, the EU has been supporting the Tribunal in different ways, using various programmes and contracts. We have banned certain persons close to the fugitives from travelling to or through EU Member States’ territory, and we froze their assets. The aim is to communicate to those affected by the conflict not only the findings of the Tribunal but also the important concepts which underpin its work. These include the concept of individual criminal responsibility, the rule of law and respect for human rights. These principles are among the core tenets shared by all members of the European Union. The Council has reiterated the need to continue handling domestic war crimes cases without discrimination, as well as addressing impunity and ensuring accountability, including through meaningful regional cooperation, as well as full cooperation with and support for the work of the Tribunal. The EU also called upon the governments concerned to pursue with greater determination the proper conduct of domestic war crime trials. The EU has made clear that political leaders should avoid statements and measures that could call into question the importance of reconciliation, and on the need to serve justice through the prosecution of war crimes. Full cooperation with the Tribunal is also addressed in the context of the Stabilisation and Association Process and is an essential condition for membership for the countries of the former Yugoslavia. For example, when accession negotiations were opened with the first country from the former Yugoslavia – Croatia – full cooperation with the Tribunal was a key requirement. Full cooperation with the Tribunal is also an essential element of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia and of its accession negotiations under Chapter 23 (Judiciary and fundamental rights). This remains a matter of concern which the European Union continues to raise with Serbia. More generally, cooperation with the Tribunal is a regular feature of the dialogue with Western Balkan partners. We are grateful to the European Parliament for the support provided during the years, especially in urging the Western Balkans’ partners to cooperate fully with the Tribunal in order to bring justice to the victims and their families, and in condemning the occasional promotion of regional intolerance and hate speech linked to the activities of the Tribunal. When the Tribunal closed down on 31 December 2017, it marked the completion of all its judicial work. The Tribunal concluded proceedings against all 161 of the individuals that were indicted for serious violations of international humanitarian law. The Tribunal’s successor – the Mechanism for International Criminal Tribunals – was established to perform a number of essential functions. This mechanism provides a further framework in which to address the reconciliation. The European Union fully respects the decisions of the Tribunal and reiterates the need for full cooperation with its successor mechanism. To conclude, let me express my sincere hope, as we look back to the last twenty years, to see the dark chapters of the Western Balkans’ history being finally put to rest.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am taking this point on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Hahn, who unfortunately cannot be here. There has never been a more timely moment to address the subject of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, or the broader issues of the legacy of past, impunity and reconciliation in the Western Balkans. These issues are directly addressed in the strategy for the Western Balkans, which the Commission adopted on 6 February. It states that ‘the process of transitional justice is incomplete. The outstanding sensitive issues, such as the handling of war crime cases, including through full cooperation with the Mechanism for International Criminal Tribunals and the Kosovo Specialist Chambers, and the fate of missing persons, refugees and internally displaced persons, as well as the identification and removal of remaining landmines in the region, must be urgently addressed. The International Tribunal has been a mainstay in the process of bringing justice to the region. As United Nations Secretary—General António Guterres said at the closing ceremony of the Tribunal in December last year, ‘The Tribunal has pushed international expectations of accountability beyond what was anticipated in 1993, transforming how we speak about, and addressing, situations in which serious international crimes are committed.’ Commissioner Hahn has been in regular contact with both the President of the International Tribunal and the chief prosecutor. Both have made it clear that its achievements would not have been possible without the European Union, without our political engagement and without our financial support – some EUR 10 million in total – and without the leverage of our accession conditionality.  So today I confirm that the commitment of the Commission is as strong as ever, stronger indeed, as we must see that the closure of the Tribunal is not the end of the matter. The successor to the Tribunal, which is the Mechanism for International Criminal Tribunals, is now well established. In the strategy which the Commission adopted recently, we are explicit in our continued support. This applies in particular to regional cooperation. Without such regional cooperation, perpetrators will continue to walk free outside the jurisdiction of national courts, and the families of the 10 000 still missing will not have their loved ones identified. Our political support is essential, but so is our financial support. Up to EUR 1 million is available this year. Our conditionality remains an integral element in the accession negotiations. More than this, it has been refined to reflect our ‘fundamentals first’ approach to the accession negotiations, allowing more thorough and detailed work than ever before. This work is set in the broader context of promoting reconciliation. We will work towards a more integrated approach, bringing many existing strands together. Not only will this include the issues of war crimes, missing persons, and also landmines, but we will also look to education, youth and culture and the ongoing regional cooperation in many fields as vectors to support the reconciliation process.  However, as our strategy adopted today clearly spells out, ‘Regional cooperation, good neighbourly relations and reconciliation cannot be imposed from outside. The leaders of the region must take full ownership and lead by example. They must avoid and condemn any statements or actions which would fuel inter—ethnic tension, and actively counter nationalist narratives.’ There must be no place in the European Union for inflammatory rhetoric, let alone for glorification of war criminals from any side. I would like the Parliament to work closely with the Commission on both of these aspects, in supporting the actions which the Commission will undertake and also in being clear in the messages that we will need to put across if reconciliation is to become a reality.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, after 24 years of investigations, the court that sentenced Slobodan Milošević, Radovan Karadžić, Ratko Mladić and also Slobodan Praljak, among others, as well as another 86 war criminals, has closed its doors at the end of last year, leaving a powerful legacy in relation to war crimes. name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr. President, the question remained open after the end of the Hague Tribunal's work. Although there have been incredible technical failures in the work of the Court, everyone should respect its decisions. No one has the right to deny the genocide in Srebrenica, as the biggest crime on European soil after World War II. No one has the right to dismiss convictions for crimes committed for alleged higher targets. There are no higher goals. Life is the highest goal. The right to life is sacred. Only sincere confrontation with the truth can bring redemption of sin for all those persons who committed, supported or covered up crimes in the territory of the former Yugoslavia.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. text: Mr President, the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague, which is primarily Yugoslavia, leaves a legacy: acquittal of the crimes of NATO and the European Union which, by inciting nationalism and irredentaliation, bombing civilians, dismantled Yugoslavia, redrawn borders, set up states, useful protectorates today in its current competition with Russia and China, making the Balkans powder keg again. name: Tonino PICULA
text: — Mr. President, the end of the Hague Tribunal was just as dramatic as its beginning, but the most dramatic were the circumstances in which it arose. The Greater Serbian aggression against Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina was passively observed by the world. The UN tribunal was finally established in 1993. It took 11 thousand days of trial to make a decision on 161 defendants; 83 were convicted and 19 acquitted. Since its founding, the Court has shown a whole range of conceptual and organisational shortcomings, unevenness of criteria, but it was a court that answered a unique challenge because of the assumption that the national courts of the countries in the war would not prosecute war crimes committed by their nationals. His mission will be discussed long and biased, and the legacy will be tested over the level of democratic maturity of the states for which it was established and their relations with each other. The tribunal was supposed to be a generator of reconciliation and confrontation with the past. However, many believe that the Court has admittedly delivered judgments, but that justice has given way to political opportune in quite a few cases.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President! As one of the few representatives of a neighbouring country of former Yugoslavia, I would like to begin with a quote: 'The Tribunal has given the victims a voice. It is clear to me that this work must be seen as an added value for law and the international community.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Mr. President, the purpose of establishing the Hague Tribunal was to punish persons responsible for serious violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of the former Yugoslavia since the beginning of 1991, so the expectations of this Court were extremely high. name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: — Mr. President, there are many objections that can be referred to the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. It is not a universal court, it only applies to some countries. The world's largest powers today are not subject to any International Criminal Court. The court left a large number of crimes without process and without punishment, drastically changed its decisions and did not have uniform criteria. The Court's reputation is small in the Western Balkans and its contribution to reconciliation is not great.
