name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Erdős, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the prospects and challenges for the apiculture sector in the EU (2017/2115 (INI) (A8-0014/2018).

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: rapporteur. — Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Unfortunately, beekeeping is rarely discussed at some meetings of the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament, although we are talking about a very important sector. On the one hand, the sector is an integral part of European agriculture, providing principal or ancillary income to more than 620,000 EU citizens. On the other hand, 84 percent of plant species and 76 per cent of European food production depend on pollination by bees. The economic value thus generated, estimated at EUR 14.2 billion per year in the EU, is significantly above the value of honey produced. Unfortunately, the importance of pollination is not sufficiently recognised in the EU and this service is taken for granted, while in the US, for example, EUR 2 billion per year is spent on artificial pollination. Therefore, the main message of my report is that beekeepers and bees should be at the heart of the EU's common agricultural policy. The EU agricultural policy of the future needs to raise the rank and funding of beekeeping to a higher level than the current one. The biggest problem is the expansion of counterfeit honey on the EU internal market. For this reason, the purchase price of honey has now halved the prices of 2014. This puts European beekeepers in a hopeless situation. Honey is the third most falsified product in the world, food, and we must fight it not only for the protection of EU beekeepers, but also for consumer protection and even public health reasons. According to the results of a study carried out by the Joint European Research Centre, 20% of the samples taken at the EU's external border posts at importers' sites were falsified honey. The fraudulent producers, mostly Chinese, are trying to cover up traces of honey-forgery by resin filtration of honey. Some honey-traders improve these syrups with high-quality European honey and sell fake honey using the label 'blend of EU and non-EU honey'. That is why, on behalf of the European Parliament, I call on the Member States and the Commission to ensure that the fraudster, especially to force certain Chinese honey producers and European honey traders to enforce the legislation. I have made a number of proposals in the report to achieve this. The cornerstone of the solution is to indicate, instead of the 'mixture of EU and non-EU honeyes', the exact country or countries in which proportion the honeycomes used in the final product come from, in the order in which the final product is used The proportion of honey contained in it looks like it. Secondly, some pesticides in many cases pose a risk to bee health. It is of particular importance that the European Parliament adopt a single, scientifically sound and firm position on this. In addition, there are serious problems with various animal diseases for beekeepers. The worst of these, the Varroa mite, has not been coped with today, since there are no drugs that could effectively destroy the parasite. I therefore call on the Commission to involve all interested pharmaceutical companies in its research and to create a common IT platform to share best solutions and medicines with stakeholders. Thirdly, EU support for beekeepers also needs to be reconsidered. While the EU's bee population grew by 48 percent between 2004 and 2016, the budget for the national apiculture programmes was only 12 percent, from 32 to 36 million euros per year. This is only 3 thousand of the budget of the CAP! Therefore, the EU budget for programmes should be increased by one and a half times the current amount. This would amount to EUR 54 million per year, still below 1% of the CAP budget.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I wish to thank the rapporteur, Mr Erdős, for his report on the apiculture sector, which clearly highlights the important issues that have been outlined in relation to the bee sector and which can certainly influence the discussions in the framework of the future common agricultural policy (CAP). The Commission shares the view of the European Parliament with regard to the importance of bees as pollinators for our environment and for agriculture, as well as the role that beekeeping could have in certain rural areas. It is precisely for this reason that the CAP currently contributes 50% of the funding of our national apicultural programmes, which are drawn down by Member States with a total EU budget of EUR 36 million per year. The report suggests that this level of support should be increased. Of course, everyone will want to increase their budget, but these are matters for discussion in the context of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the CAP reform. The Commission is also developing an EU Pollinators Initiative to establish an integrated approach to tackle the decline of pollinators. The aim is to raise the political profile and increase the effectiveness of existing EU policies for pollinators. The main objective of the national apicultural programmes is to improve the conditions for the production and marketing of honey. Given the importance of bees, not just as honey producers but also as pollinators, the Commission supports them by other means as well. Under the first pillar of the CAP, 30% of the direct payments are linked to environment-friendly farming practices, while pillar II supports agri-environment climate measures which also contribute to improving the environment for bees. While the report suggests stronger Commission involvement in various research and education projects in the EU, we should also keep in mind the value of the national programmes, which are adapted to the needs of specific Member States. Nevertheless, the Commission is closely involved in research activities in relation to apiculture, including the EU pilot project on breeding and selection program for research in the resistance against the Varroa mite. This was recently initiated by Parliament, and work was done by the Joint Research Centre on methods for detection of honey adulteration. The Commission also established, and continues to cofinance, an EU reference laboratory for bee health, and it frequently liaises with the European Food Safety Authority for scientific advice on various areas such as pathogens or pesticides. The Commission is well aware of the concerns about adulteration of honey, in response to which the Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (DG SANTE) launched an EU-wide coordinated control plan on honey quality in 2015. The preliminary results indicate that adulteration, for example by adding sugar, is not only a problem with imported honey but also takes place within the European Union itself. The Commission is committed to ensuring that honey put on the market complies with EU standards and it is currently analysing how best to do this, although the Commission is not convinced that new rules on origin labelling for honey could solve the problem. The CAP also provides many possibilities for promoting honey. Member States can include in their national apicultural programmes measures such as market monitoring or enhancement of product quality, with a view to exploiting the potential of products on the market. In addition, the sector is eligible for most promotion topics in the internal market and in third countries, and honey can be promoted under the EU quality scheme, either because of a specific link to a certain region or because it is produced in a specific traditional manner. The EU School Fruit, Vegetables and Milk Scheme that applies from 1 August 2017 gives Member States the possibility of including honey in educational measures to be carried out in order to reconnect children with agriculture. The scheme aims to promote healthy eating habits and requires Member States to ensure the appropriate involvement of their national authorities responsible for health and nutrition in drawing up the list of products to be provided to schoolchildren. Several Member States, namely France, Italy, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Greece, Lithuania, Austria, Romania and Slovenia, include honey in these educational measures.  Mr Erdős’ report accurately reflects the importance of the beekeeping sector, and I have outlined some of the issues on which we can do more together. Perhaps many people are not aware of these particular measures which can be exploited to even better potential by Member States than they are now, through the apicultural programmes. I think it is clear that the sector is already well integrated into the CAP through these measures and it also benefits from targeted, as well as general, measures. I acknowledge that the report suggests we can do more and provide additional support, so we welcome the constructive suggestions from Parliament and I am sure they will provide food for thought, and honey, as the Commission prepares its legislative proposals for the CAP post-2020.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I would like to thank Mr Erdős sincerely for his work, who is going to be in the right direction by calling on the Commission and the Member States to ban neonicotinoids. The problem is that this ban is conditional not only on laboratory tests, but also to field tests. However, the latter are considered to be too few, which has the effect of delaying a necessary comprehensive ban. This debate is strangely similar to the debate on glyphosate, for which we are promised a ban which is constantly postponed. Furthermore, the Commission considers, in its written reply of 1 September 2017, that neonicotinoids used in greenhouse crops are not dangerous for bees and therefore cannot be completely banned. However, these substances, even used in greenhouses, are persistent in soils and also in water. It is therefore a real danger when we know that these neonicotinoids will only disappear after several years. In 2015, EFSA confirmed that the use of this type of pesticides in the form of foliar spraying poses a risk to bees. Even today, a particularly awaited EFSA report confirms the perceived — and I quote — “high” risk for three neonicotinoids currently subject to restrictions on use in the European Union. Therefore, in order to avoid any misuse or illegal use of these substances and in order to stop the decline of bees, the general prohibition is an absolute urgency. That is precisely the subject of my amendment which will be put to the vote tomorrow in plenary. This is true of the future of mankind.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, firstly, I would like to congratulate Mr Erdős, but also those who contributed to the completion of this report. The beekeeping sector is one of the most vulnerable sectors in agriculture, whether only if we consider extreme weather phenomena, the invasion of the European market with falsified honey products or the use, often irrational, of pesticides. Given that 84% of plant species and 76% of food production in Europe depend on bee pollination, we have the exact size of the sector's importance, not just for agriculture, but for the whole world. In this context, I consider that the following objectives must be achieved. One: continuing the financial support of the sector and increasing its amount beyond 2020. Promoting and supporting the cultivation of honey plants that benefit from consistent support, just like protein plants. Effectively combating imports of honey from countries where the use of antibiotics is not regulated, as well as counterfeit honey. It is also necessary to intensify innovation and research activities in order to identify pesticides that ensure sustainable agriculture, but also to protect the beekeeping sector effectively. Finally, I believe that Member States must understand the need to support and encourage associative forms in the sector, so that beekeepers, through joint efforts, create their own production, packaging and sales capacities, but at the same time reduce the administrative burden associated with these activities. Let's not forget that by saving bees, we save humanity.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Honourable Members, today's report is a very important step for beekeeping in the European Union. All over 600 000 Europeans who care for bees and beekeeping should receive adequate support and funding for the care they take. Pollination is a major function of bees and is an ecological service to be repaid. In the new CAP, this must be a fact. Earlier today, EFSA issued a clear opinion on three neonicotinoids. They harm bees and are one of the serious causes of mortality in them. I call on the competent authorities in the Member States and especially in Bulgaria to comply with these facts. A serious problem is also imports from third countries. Bulgarian producers felt strong pressure from copper from Ukraine and China. European consumers have the right to know what products they consume and where they originate. In this regard, I am pleased that my proposal for country origin designation, as well as the percentage of each, has become part of the report. This report is a good basis for Europe's new apiculture policy, so I will support it.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President. There is an old saying in Germany, which means that if the bees die, then humans die too. This is the drama of current developments. I am glad that today we are working intensively on the prospects and challenges for the apiculture sector in the EU. Without bees, there would be no honey; fruits and vegetables would also become luxury goods. The animals pollinate about 80% of our crops and wild plants. Failure to maintain bee populations and insects will die out, this would have fatal consequences for humans and developments are dramatic. We must act and no longer close our eyes. We need to shed light on the many possible causes, and we must be honest: pesticides based on neonicotinoids are a major problem for our bees and all insects. I call for measures to prohibit the production, sale and use of all neonicotinoid pesticides in the Union without exception and as a priority measure to protect the bee population. It is a radical step; we will only be able to take it in close dialogue with farmers. It's not about pointing your finger at a culprit. No, it is about preserving and protecting the bees as the basis of our environment. It's about leaving our children an environment in which it buzzes and blooms. We share the responsibility for this — today.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. We are all aware of the great importance of bee colonies for the cultural landscape and the contribution to the preservation of biodiversity. With its pollination performance, the honeybee is an important link in many communities. 84% of agricultural yields are only possible through pollination by insects. Our report identifies difficult issues, but also identifies solutions. I would like to name them as a ledder: research into the fight against varroa mite is important. Lithium chloride is not yet ready for the market. However, the education and training of our young impees is just as important. For me, dialogue with farmers is an elementary basis. The time of mowing and ultimately crop protection in the evening and a bee app are good guidelines here. The reduction of contaminated wax from China, which endangers bee health; the use of pesticides on a scientific basis by EFSA. Finally, I would like to say that, in the bus procedure, we have indeed taken bee plants into account here and are becoming aware of our responsibilities.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Madam President, Commissioner, as has already been said here, it is of great importance to protect bees, wild pollinators and European beekeeping. This report, which I support, has many measures to do so and, even more so, with broad consensus. I'll report some of them. Prohibit dangerous active substances in pesticides: neocotinoids are also systemic insecticides. I support the protection of bees against invasive species such as Vespa velutina. Increase legal protection and financial support for ecotypes and endemic local honeybee populations throughout the European Union, including also the protection of conservation areas for these bees. Support pilot projects on bees and other pollinators, as indicators of environmental health and habitat. Establish the labelling with the exact indication of the country or countries of origin in the fight against fraudulent honey.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, in 2013, when Greens were on the streets with environmentalists and beekeepers campaigning for a ban on all neonicotinoid pesticides due to their harmful effects on bees, it felt like we were banging our heads against a brick wall. Five years later, we find ourselves pushing against an open door, as there is widespread agreement about the negative effects of these substances and more and more people, including Michael Gove, are coming together to call for a ban. But insuring that our bees survive and thrive is not a single-issue matter. As noted in this report, intensive farming reduces the range of flowering crops for bees to feed on, and the heavy load of agricultural chemicals bees are exposed to weakens them, making them vulnerable to stresses like wet weather, a lack of nectar, diseases, and parasites. Bees are an essential part of our agricultural system, but the web of nature is delicate and complicated. We must promote a farming system that works with and not against nature if we are to give bees a chance.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all aware of the fundamental role bees play. We said it: 84% of the overall plant species and 76% of food production depend on bee pollination, with an estimated total economic value of €14.2 billion. In the face of these numbers, we call for Parliament and the Commission, with a clear and clear stance, to stand in defence of bees and the sector that cares for them. We call for a ban on the use of all substances that are proven harmful against bees, such as notorious neonicotinoids, and a cautionary suspension of substances with suspicion . We call for measures to support crop diversification, recovery of ecological areas, preservation of genetic diversity of local bee populations. We also ask to ensure the health of the citizens of the products of this supply chain are consumed: from third countries are imported more and more quantities of altered honey or produced following far more permissive rules than European ones. We want tighter controls on imports. We want a clear label that will tell us if we are eating honey or mixtures of other artificial substances; we want a mandatory label on the true provenance of honey. We cannot settle for the single indication “European honey” or “non-European honey”: we want complete traceability.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Madam President, I congratulate my colleague Erdős on the report that is crucial for the beekeeping sector in the European Union because it comprehensively identifies the problems of beekeeping and pollination and proposing measures that should support bee conservation efforts at European and Member State level and other pollinators. I am glad that my amendments have been adopted, which I have submitted with the support of colleagues from European commoners, which put emphasis on the demand for increased funding of the beekeeping sector, ensuring quality honey for consumers and protecting bee communities. For more than half a million Union citizens, beekeeping is a source of main income, while food production and biodiversity conservation depend on pollination carried out by bees. I therefore call on the European Commission to increase the funding of beekeeping in a way that would adequately support the important ecological service of bees as pollinators and to include a new system of direct support for beekeepers per bee community. I also ask that the Honey Labelling Directive be amended so that European consumers know the exact origin of the honey they buy. Finally, I can proudly point out that Croatia is one of the few Member States implementing measures to protect domestic bee species and I want other countries to get involved in it as soon as possible.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate and thank Mr Erdős for this report, and to welcome the work done by Momchil Nekov, on behalf of the Socialist Group, on a subject of utmost importance. Bees disappear at an alarming rate. Yet pollination, as many have said, plays an absolutely essential role in our food security and biodiversity. Land-use changes and intensive farming practices bear — it seems to me — a heavy responsibility for the decline of the European beekeeping herd. There is an urgent need to turn to a model that is less dependent on pesticides and insecticides and that increases the value of ecosystem services. This development requires an urgent reform of the CAP, which we want more to focus on agro-ecology. We need to help better structure and professionalize beekeeping sectors and increase research to combat pests such as varroa destructor. Finally, I call for future agricultural policy to identify apitherapy as a priority and to enhance the multiple medical properties of honey and pollen.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Madam President! The European Food Safety Authority is not necessarily known for distributing green content. In this particular case, EFSA itself has recommended the use of neonicotinoids in the field. If, at the same time, we realize that diversity in our agriculture and working with nature is the way forward, then we can learn the lesson of bees. I would urge all of you — as an active farmer and as an active beekeeper on behalf of my colleagues — to support this report — for healthy food, healthy agriculture and for saving bees.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, I wonder how many MEPs have seen the disease in sugar beet called Virus Yellows? It is absolutely devastating. Aphids infect the young plant with this virus, and within weeks the leaves all go yellow, and yields can be as low as 25% of what you might reasonably expect. Neonicotinoid seed dressings have prevented this problem. The Green lobby wish to ban these dressings in the interest of bee health. Sugar beet is a biennial crop. It is harvested in its first year before it flowers. Bees are not interested to visit it at this stage. If these seed dressings are banned by the EU, beet growers will be forced to apply repeated sprays of the insecticide called cypermethrin, with all the ground being covered each time. Seed dressings, on the other hand, affect less than 1% of the ground. We are already witnessing some resistance to cypermethrin insecticides. The more they are used, the worse this problem becomes. Colony collapse disorder and verroa mite are the big enemy of bees, not sugar beet seed dressings. If they are to be banned, a viable alternative must be found, and for goodness sake, let us look at GM technology, which has a solution to this problem.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: - Madam President! Today, EFSA released its long-awaited report into the effects of neonicotinoids on bee health. The first step in addressing this issue should be to deepen dialogue between different parties in order to achieve the best possible results under the current system. That is, further increasing the quality of the plant protection products used, better selecting the period during which they are used, and such activities. If farmers are to achieve this, they need to have some knowledge. At the same time, the industry should increase its research funds and develop more environmentally friendly plant protection products and fight against counterfeiting cases. We should be aware that the ban on official plant protection products will lead to a black market where products of questionable quality will be sold and of much greater harm. Then there will only be a tragedy. Therefore, when imposing a restriction dialogue, it should also be given to farmers some alternatives. Only dialogue and understanding can help us build sustainable agriculture.

name: Pavel POC
text: – Madam President, and of course congratulations to the rapporteur and shadows, indeed the result is not bad at all. I specially welcome paragraph 33 calling for a ban of some systemic plant production products, including neonicotinoids. EFSA has published an updated risk assessment today of three neonicotinoids – clothianidin, imidacloprid and thiamethoxam – that are currently subject to restrictions in the EU because they pose a threat to bees. The Authority highlights that most studies show that neonicotinoids have a negative impact on bee health, from damaging their orientation capacity to impairing their reproductive ability. Given the scientific evidence that clearly proves those substances are harmful to pollinators, I expect the Member States to vote for a complete ban of neonicotinoids during the upcoming meeting of the  PAFF Committee on 24 March this year.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: — Madam President, beekeeping is one of the most important sectors of agriculture, but unfortunately also one of the most neglected, both by national and European authorities. The sums granted under national apiculture programmes are insufficient to meet the challenges faced by beekeepers. Bees make an extremely important contribution to pollination and biodiversity preservation, which is why bee mortality - caused by both climate change and insecticides - should not be ignored. I hope that, in future, the Commission will reconsider granting derogations for the use of these substances in predominantly apiculture areas. I would also like to ask the Commission to review the Consumer Information Directive as well as the Honey Directive, in order to ensure that only products containing 100% honey and not mixtures with honey can be marketed under that name.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I have a lot of speeches. That is why I have decided to take only one per group. Please do not complain to me, but to your colleagues who have not kept to their speaking times, which has meant that we have already been very late. Spontaneous Speaking

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President! This report also addresses an important area, namely market distortions for European beekeepers. At the moment, we are allowing honey importers — and quite rightly — to mix their commodities with small amounts of European honey and then simply declare this as a mixture of honey from EU and non-EU countries. I therefore call very clearly that 'EU' must only stand on it if at least 50% of EU honey is inside. And I also call for the percentage of honey from non-EU countries to be declared as a percentage. This is fair in the interests of European beekeepers and it is fair to consumers. We do not need deceptive designations of origin, but clear: where the EU is inside, 'EU' can be on it.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, there are school programmes at Union level to encourage the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk, which allows Member States to include other local specialities such as honey in these programmes. Given the nutritional benefits of honey, the importance of beekeeping and encouraging the consumption of honey and beekeeping products, I recommend the involvement of local beekeepers in these programmes and I consider it necessary to include a new system of support for beekeepers in the post-2020 CAP. Europe needs advanced early warning systems shared between farmers and beekeepers, foresters, scientists and veterinarians, on spraying periods and other forms of insecticide application, disease prevention and control, non- harmful to bees, as well as plant protection methods that minimize the quality of pollinators. I propose to diversify educational programmes at basic and professional level in the field of beekeeping, in order to encourage young people to choose the profession of beekeeper, to renew generations in the sector.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, beekeeping is an important factor in supporting the standard of living of populations in mountainous and remote areas. Measures are needed to protect beekeepers and consumers from unfair practices, since adulterated honey has flooded the internal market due to large imports from Turkey, China and Ukraine. Measures should be taken to impose a procedure for traceability, labelling and labelling of imported honey. In addition, measures are needed to deal with the disease of varroasis, as well as applied research to eradicate this disease and to support beekeepers with funding for the production of queens and the purchase of beekeepers. They also need funding for seasonal travel, training programmes and, finally, the designation of honey as a Designation of Origin Product.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: — Madam President, I would like to recall on this occasion when we launched a manifestation that we called Honey Days in Pazin, Istria, quite a few years ago in Pazin, Istria. So much enthusiasm, so much love for that product and for the bees themselves, indeed, I can say that in my twenty-seven years of political career I have not seen. So much happiness and satisfaction that we made such a single manifestation and so much satisfaction from consumers who came to that event, it was really rare to see. That is why I am confident that the two topics discussed here today should be given priority. Support honey producers, beekeepers, through the new Common Agricultural Policy and, of course, protecting their product. Without protecting their product, we will roam again, again we will not know what is on our table, what we eat and how healthy it is. That is why I am confident that this report and what Mr Commissioner said are going in that direction and I want to believe that beekeeping will have a new status in the European Union after 2020.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President! I wholeheartedly congratulate my compatriot Norbert Erdős, who is the reporter of this very important and beautiful report, from which we can learn almost everything we need to know about honey, bees and beekeeping. Let me ask if I understand correctly that if someone wants to be a responsible honey consumer together with his family, then as a Hungarian — Hungary, by the way, is one of the three main European honey-producing countries — is to acquire it from the market or directly from the producer. , so that the Hungarian person should consume Hungarian honey if possible. This may be a different nationalist or extremist stamp, but let me say, and then let me turn to the Commissioner and ask him whether I understand correctly that a lot of falsified honey is coming to Europe, especially from China, and many of these are health. It's harmful. Let me ask you, what are you doing specifically against this, as I understand, organized crime? I stress that the most harmful effects of this can be avoided if we consume local honey produced locally. I guess I did. I look forward to confirmation from the rapor.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the report and this evening’s discussion have clearly showed that there is significant interest here in Parliament and broad support for the collective efforts that are being made to ensure a healthy apiculture sector in the European Union. It is also true to say that the importance of the sector is widely recognised and the value of the support already available under the CAP is appreciated. Everybody believes that we should do more, and perhaps we can do more. It is worth noting that the budget in 2014 was doubled over the previous programming period, so there is already a recognition in the 2014-2020 programmes of the increasing importance of honey in the agricultural industry. While I cannot pre-empt what is going to happen in the next budget, it is certainly safe to say that the Members here that have spoken will be keeping a close eye on the financial programmes for the post-2020 period. A number of Members expressed their concern at the use of neonicotinoids and referenced the updated risk assessments in relation to three particular neonicotinoids which EFSA has published today. Today’s conclusions will now be shared with the Commission and the Member States, and I am sure that my colleague who is the relevant Commissioner in this area, Commissioner Andriukaitis, will be taking note on, and a close interest in, this report. Today’s report does not make any reference in terms of a possible ban. The Commission and the Member States will now have to consider whether or not to introduce possible amendments to the current restrictions on the use of these pesticides. I noted what Mr Agnew said in relation to the banning of some of these neonicotinoids in respect of sugar beet, and I agree with his analysis. He has certainly indicated very clearly what I believe to be the case in relation to sugar beet and the possible exemptions in relation to the application of neonicotinoids in relation to sugar beet. I think it is also worth noting as well that this Parliament voted in very substantial numbers to approve a proposal from the Commission in relation to the banning in ecological focus areas of the use of pesticides, and this has made a major impact – a positive impact – in relation to the application of this new rule, in my view, in 2018 in terms of what will happen where more than 10% of the total arable area of the European Union will now have a ban on pesticides in these areas. I think this is a major step forward for which this House can be proud in terms of the vote that it expressed in 2017. So in conclusion, I again want to reiterate my appreciation to Mr Erdős for his report. I think it has a sound basis for working together in order to improve the supports in the various ways that I have outlined in my initial contribution to the apiculture sector.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Allow me to thank the Commissioner, the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and all my fellow Members very much. 486amendments have been tabled, this means extra much, and by the way, we have been able to push 90 per cent of these 486 into a compromise, 36 separate votes It's just, so it's really, really wide, there's a lot of support for this case. Thank you all very much for your work! Please allow me to repeat that without successful beekeepers and healthy bees, there will be no pollination and honey in Europe in the future, so we must stand up for a programme that guarantees the survival of bees and beekeepers. This programme is a text before you, conceived by the beekeepers themselves and formed with the active participation of all parliamentary groups, based on a fragile balance between the interests of the faction. The fight against honey-counterfeiting, the effective and immediate protection of bees against truly harmful chemicals, the fight against bee diseases or the need for fairer EU support for beekeepers are questions to which the EU's democratically agreed response is not may be postponed further. One of the topics, the issue of pesticides, is one of the most sensitive issues in the European Parliament today. When we decide on this, we must take into account the protection of farmers, the avoidance of a decline in agricultural production and the protection of the environment, habitats, indigenous plants and animals with the same weight. During the preparation of the honey report, we managed to incorporate a balanced and sensible solution into the report as a result of long and laborious negotiations. Active substances of pesticides that have been proven to be harmful to bee health should be immediately banned. And what is harmful, on a scientific basis, has to be said by EFSA. This solution was accepted by all factions. I ask that we also approach the tabled modifiers on this basis. I count on the vote on the honey report with their full support. Please continue to support me in the future when I act in favour of European beekeepers and bees.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 1 March 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — Through this own-initiative report, the European Parliament is once again showing leadership in the protection of bees and is up to the challenge. The decline of bees is reaching record levels in Europe and calls for a coordinated approach to responding to multiple pollinator mortality factors. Local initiatives in favour of bees are abundant, but European and national policy objectives remain far below expectations. Budgets are ridiculous today compared to the agricultural and ecological services of pollinators, such as bees. As President of the European BeeWeek, BeeWeek, I am delighted that this report builds on our work undertaken since 2012. We offer concrete solutions to address the main challenges of the beekeeping industry, in particular on bee health, pest control, research programmes, beehive product protection, labelling or combating corrugated honey. I call on the European Commission and the Member States to take up these proposals and present ambitious policy objectives for the beekeeping sector without delay.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. — Hungary is the third largest honey-producing country in the EU. This sector is the main livelihood for about twenty thousand Hungarian beekeepers. 75% of Hungarian honey goes to the EU market, but large quantities of honey come from outside the EU (for example, from China), most of which are falsified. We therefore have an important interest in combating honey-counterfeiting, effective protection of bees against actual harmful chemicals, adequate EU support for beekeepers, measures to combat bee diseases. The report by my colleague Norbert Erdős on the prospects and challenges facing the EU beekeeping sector is very timely. In order to protect Hungarian beekeepers, a reliable monitoring and product marking system at EU level is necessary, and Norbert Erdős honey report is a decisive step in this direction.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. — A handful of monopolies are also in charge of the honey sector. With the state-of-the-art methods they have developed, they can utilize any origin of honey, relieving it from any traces of its locality (eg pollen), and mix it with honey from another region, baptizing it as they want. Euro-unifying regulations allow them to do so because they do not consider the mixing of honey to be fraudgy and the report does not even call for it to be abolished. In Greece, where honey is produced of excellent quality, small producers are eliminated by this situation, which is exacerbated by the anti-grassroots policy of the government, with the blessings of the EU. Any tightening of the Euro-Union standards is used as a tool to give major groups a lead in global competition. It is not based on product quality and public health, but on the profit of large companies. The Communist Party of Greece calls for immediate measures, such as tax relief and reduction of production costs, to bring real relief to small and medium-sized beekeepers.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. — The protection of the beekeeping sector should not be linked exclusively to honey production, as it entails the important aspect of crop pollination and biodiversity conservation. About 80% of cultivated plants need insects to be pollinated. However, we are witnessing, without warning, a dramatic reduction in insect populations worldwide. Thanks to the beekeeping sector we noticed this effect. Although the modification of the territory is an important factor in the decline of insect populations, the use of pesticides such as neonicotinoids, applied worldwide since the 1980s, is the main cause of the global decline in bee populations. Its effects last in the environment long after using them. Although the use of these insecticides was restricted in the EU in 2013, their prohibition is necessary as the permissible applications remain an aggression to the natural environment that we cannot afford.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. — Bees play a key role in pollinating trees and plants. But their colonies are now under threat. Action must be taken to reduce bee mortality, including by banning pesticides that are hazardous to their health. Developing a European action plan to protect bees, which would improve the resilience of colonies to mites and other sources of destruction is only a minimum. This must pass through a ban on the most harmful pesticides, including neonicotinoids. Europe must do everything possible to avoid the environmental disaster that could result from the disappearance of bees. I therefore call on you to support the amendments calling on the Commission and the Member States to put in place measures to strengthen legal protection and financial support for honeybee ecotypes throughout the European Union, including through the establishment of conservation areas, protected by law, endemic honeybees and calling on the Commission to urgently propose legislation prohibiting the production, sale and use of all neonicotinoid pesticides throughout the Union, without possible derogation, in order to protect bee populations.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: Written. — I believe that the importance of the beekeeping sector in the European Union is much greater than the statistical indicators themselves if we know enough the meaning of honey as food and health value of bee products. Beekeeping really has to be at the heart of Europe's agricultural policy, so it is important to increase funding for beekeeping which is currently not at the level of meaning it for the quality of life of EU citizens. I support increasing the budget for annual programmes from the current €36m to 47 million euros as proposed in the report. It is necessary to strengthen the promotional activities of healthy eating and the health value of bee products, honey, propolis and others. Croatia, in addition to Bulgaria, Romania, Portugal, Spain, France and Hungary, belongs to those countries of the European Union which, due to their biodiversity and tradition of beekeeping, can offer the highest quality honey and for this reason we must successfully oppose imports at the level of the European Union Patvorena honey from China, to protect consumers and our beekeepers and in general human health. We must stand very strongly for the European beekeeping sector, quality honey for our consumers and better conditions for our beekeepers, and against imports of patvorene honey, forgery hidden behind unspecified labels without the necessary data on the country of origin and the type of honey.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — I want to draw attention to one serious issue concerning environmental protection in the EU. I don't know if it's widely known the fact that 25 million wild birds are shot every year in the Mediterranean, often by totally illegal means. Unfortunately, EU states, most Italy, Cyprus and Greece, also participate in this activity. It should be noted that these countries violate international obligations, the Bonn and Berne Conventions, but also European law, namely the directive on the protection of wild birds. So I call on the European Commission to address this problem, so that we really act in accordance with European law and, crucially, to provide protection for animals on EU territory in accordance with what We adopted directives here on the floor of the EP.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Madam President, the fact that a journalist and his partner were intentionally murdered in my country fills me with sadness, shame and anger. I'm sad because two young lives have been extinguished. I am ashamed because the published revelations of this journalist showed that people suspected of connecting to international crime have been living and doing business in Slovakia for years. If you feel that it is above our strength to investigate the murder of Jan Kuciak and to come to terms with the revelations he has brought, please give us a helping hand.

text: Madam President, at a time when Turkey invades Syria and slaughters civilians and young children, at a time when it continues to threaten the islands of Greece, while it continues to illegally own 40% of the Republic of Cyprus, when it invades the Exclusive Economic Zone of a Member State of the European Union in order to prevent the exploitation of hydrocarbon deposits that will benefit the whole of Europe, some must stop thinking about any scenarios of upgrading relations between the European Union and Turkey. name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: — Madam President, in this plenary of the European Parliament, allow me to express my sincere condolences to the survivors of the murdered journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancee. As you know, there has been a serious premeditated murder of a journalist in Slovakia. This heinous act has shook Slovakia, and I see that the whole of Europe and the distant abroad too. There is talk of freedom of speech, which we all appreciate, and it is always necessary to fight for it. No less serious suspicions are starting to come to light. Organised crime rebuilt a serious problem for several Central European countries in the 1990s. And if it turns out that there is really an international mafia behind the murder of a 27-year-old journalist, with possible links to high Slovak government posts, the whole of Europe should be on the alarm. A possible mafia connection to the highest Slovak government circles is also a strong biting for a country that has been swept up in serious corruption scandals for the past few years. I want to refer from here to all interested and particularly post-communist governments, we refuse to make the murder of an investigative journalist a new norm. We belong to a civilised world where organised crime has no place and where killers must be caught and punished for their act.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, European construction integrates diversity by building new ways of being a State and a nation. It has created shared sovereignies and practices focused on better responding to the needs and will of citizens. On the same basis, my party has tabled in the Basque Country a proposal which, within the law, is committed to permanent dialogue, respect and recognition in order to update the structure of a Member State which is said to be plurinational. We are committed to a voluntary union of nations that exist and want to turn into force constitutional principles into reality. Thus we provide stability and solutions. I therefore call on Brussels and Strasbourg, in order to prevent new conflicts, to protect this commitment to coexistence against the same antiquated state nationalism which they criticize as the worst enemy of European construction; to force those who remain stuck in nineteenth century concepts to respect laws and agreements, to dialogue and dialogue and build. Remind them that lashing into giants when there are mills in front of us is incompatible with our Union, because this feeds national populism throughout the continent.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: — Madam President, Carlos Santiago, Josep Pàmies, Nacho Carretero, Xavier Uriarte, Santiago Sierra have in common been victims of censorship in the last two weeks in the Spanish State. A carnival trading session, conferences, a rap, a book, a photo exhibition are subjects censored in different ways but all correspond to the authoritarianism of the People's Party. This afternoon, Commissioner Jourová said that freedom of expression was untouchable; it must be respected regardless of our views. I ask you, Commissioner, how many more complaints we should make so that this Parliament and the European Commission can react to ensure that human rights, such as freedom of expression, are respected in the Spanish State.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: — Madam President, Slovakia has been shocked by the news of the premeditated murder of a young journalist and his fiancée. It affects not only their families, but the whole country. As a journalist, the man collected reports of corruption and tax evasion, which, according to his hyped findings, go to the highest places. Democracy in Slovakia has been seriously undermined by this contentious murder. Journalist Ján Kuciak searched and found what many wished to keep secret. He sought the truth for Slovakia, not for himself. I therefore call on the security forces and the prosecutor's office to investigate the case without delay, detect the criminals and punish the murderers. And if the government should also fall on it, I ask for help in completing the work of this brave Slovak, and I also call on the European Community. Let us not allow a citizen in Slovakia to lose faith in justice, order and truth.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, a recent report published by John Mann, a member of the British Parliament in my region of the UK, has evidenced a significant inequity and unfairness in the way arts, culture and sport are funded. London has received GBP 8 from the Arts Council in the UK for every GBP 1 received by former coalfield communities in my region. For Sport England it was GBP 4 to GBP 1. I suggest it is now time for all public funding for sport, the arts and culture – including EU funding – to be audited with regard to that geographic inequity and unfairness. Whether you live in a city, a rural village or a former industrial community, all young people and, indeed, all citizens have an equal right to access to the arts, culture and sport.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the European Council of 23 February 2018 had the opportunity to send a decisive message to Erdoğan and Turkey, Turkey, which is now openly threatening Greece with war, Turkey which violates Greek territorial waters in the Aegean Sea, imposes illegal maritime blockade in Imia and rams a Greek Coast Guard vessel in Turkey, which, acting as a modern pirate, wants to seize the underwater wealth of the Cyprus EEZ, where there are very rich deposits of natural gas and oil. The Tusk message to Erdoğan had to be more decisive and had to be combined with the imposition of political diplomatic, military and economic sanctions against Ankara. The European Council should have already imposed a complete and complete ban on the sale of military equipment to Ankara and a series of harsh economic sanctions, because only that is the language the Sultan understands. But the European Council stayed up and threw the ball on the platform.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: — Madam President, at the last session of the Parliament I warned the Commission about the opposition of the regional authorities of the Primorje-Gorski Kotar County and local authorities of the island of Krk, especially the municipality of Omišalj, bringing a floating LNG terminal to Omišalj. I have to do that on this occasion. It is amazing that with 101 million euros we are funding a project that we want to impose on one local environment. Citizens and NGOs are completely arguably opposed to the floating terminal, but accept the land that already has all the necessary documents, even has a location permit. Why don't we accept the hand provided on their part? I do not know where in Europe local environments have decided to accept in a constructive way such heavy, demanding industrial facilities. It takes an open, honest dialogue with no fingers crossed in your pocket. So I guess for the overall energy strategy of the European Union it is not crucial whether in Croatia is LNG terminal on land or is it floating? It is important that we build a terminal that suits everyone.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, on 8 March, women around the world are called on to strike worldwide to denounce a system, patriarchal, that invades all aspects of women's lives — not just the 17% wage gap in this Union or the marginality of political spaces to women — and to make women visible those invisible jobs. It is in the judicial system and in the many sentences clearly against women in family cases; it is in the pension gap of about 40% in the Union; it is in the violence suffered by one in three women throughout their life; and it is on the burden of care, which continues to fall mostly on us women. It is in advertising, sexist treatment of news, in the media and in digital media; it is in sexual harassment, in differentiated education and is in the sexual division of labour. Patriarchy, for us, is a monster we must fight against, and the best tool is to make it visible that the world, if we stop, stops, and that without cross-cutting gender policies, there is and will not be possible change.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the imperialist antagonisms of the European Union and the Polish Government are intensifying on the pretext of justice. Behind them, of course, there are great interests. At the same time, they are not saying a word that tomorrow, 1 March, the Communist Party of Poland and its officials will be dragged back to the courts on charges of propaganda of communist ideology in the newspaper Brzask and on its website, with threats of two years of imprisonment. In anti-communism, you see, the European Union and the Polish Government find out and agree. We condemn anti-communist measures and persecution, we condemn the prohibitions on communist symbols and the spread of communist ideas. We condemn that, at the same time, it is the greatest challenge to pay tribute to the Nazi collaborators, to equate the fascist monster born and bred by the capitalist system with communism. We demand immediate revocation of all prosecutions against the Polish Communist Party, its members and officials. The suppression of historical truth and anti-communism will not pass.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: — Madam President, I recently talked to dozens of farmers in my region about the difficulties they face in carrying out their work. The major problem is determined by massive imports of food products, which deprives them of a market for domestic products. In 2017, according to the INS, food amounting to 5.1 billion euros entered Romania, while the export was only a few hundred million euros. Their difficulties derive from the fact that the price of imported and marketed products in Romania is well below the cost price. Thus, a domestic farmer who owns a pig farm, slaughterhouse and his own marketing space must sell a kilogram of meat at 3.5 Euro to survive on the market. Imported meat is sold in supermarkets for a price of just 2.5 euros, well below the cost price in any part of Europe. Without an effective fight against unfair competition, Romania risks becoming a country without domestic farmers and a huge market for food produced in other countries, in other words, unfair competition is a delayed atomic bomb for farmers in Romania.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this photo I am showing you illustrates one of the biggest breaches of the Water Framework Directive that is taking place today in the European Union. On the left is the Tagus River — the main river of the Iberian Peninsula — with very little water as a result of transfers to the Levante, and on the right is one of its tributaries, the Jarama River, with much more water and totally contaminated by poor purification that occurs mainly in the Community of Madrid. This photo is the consequence of the bad water policies being made by the Government of Spain; the fact that there is so little water prevents good dilution, causing serious pollution of the Tagus River. Commissioner, I would ask you to transfer to the College of Commissioners, now that you have to evaluate the basin plans — in this case the Tago River — that will correct this serious damage to the environment in one of Europe's main rivers.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, tonight in Ireland there are 9 000 homeless people, thousands more are on housing waiting lists, and for a whole generation home ownership is an aspiration they will never realise. Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael governments have failed them, but they’ve never failed the banks. A decade ago, PTSB was bailed out with EUR 3 billion in Irish taxpayers’ money. Today that bank is planning to sell off 14 000 family homes with distressed mortgages to vulture funds, and other banks are following suit. The vultures are gathering because people can’t repay their loans because the Irish banking cartel has implemented such high mortgage rates. The vulture funds are unregulated, aggressive and vicious in the pursuit of profits. Our government must rein in the banks and the vulture funds. The European Central Bank and the Commission too, so quick to burden the Irish people with 42% of Europe’s bank debt, cannot ignore a crisis that they have had a hand in creating. Banks should be prevented from selling distressed home mortgages to vulture funds: it’s as simple as that. For once and for all, it’s time to side with mortgage-holders and home-owners instead of banks.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President! Yesterday in the European Parliament, we discussed the future relations between the EU and Ukraine, the performance of Ukraine in the field of reforms and European integration. I believe that Ukraine's perspectives are greatly influenced by democratic rights and freedoms, including the guarantee of minority rights, legal certainty and social peace. Meanwhile, in the westernmost county of Ukraine, the headquarters of the Transcarpathian Hungarian Cultural Association in Uzhhorod was attacked for the second time in a month. Unknown unsub has planted an explosive device, which, as a result of an explosion, the lower level of the headquarters was completely burnt out. This can be seen as a direct threat and intimidation of the Hungarians in Transcarpathia, which must not be left unspoken by the European Union. They must clearly condemn this terrorist act and call on the Ukrainian authorities to find out as soon as possible the identity of the perpetrator, the customers and the motivation of the case. Certain forces are increasingly working to upset order and peace in the western part of the country, to provoke and provoke ethnic conflicts, to which the EU must respond.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, terrorism in Europe can be fought effectively only with close cooperation between national authorities. So I welcome Theresa May’s commitment to the UK’s continued participation in Europol and the European arrest warrant. Ms May’s Munich speech was, from beginning to end, an argument against Britain leaving the European Union. But let’s take her at face value. She says the UK will respect the remit of the European Court of Justice when participating in the agencies, will continue to align its rules on data-sharing and will do all that is necessary to ensure that evidence gathered is admissible in court. It remains to be seen quite how she intends to sell that to the Brexit extremists in her party, who oppose the ECJ on ideological grounds and would be soft on terrorism. I look forward to more of this pragmatism on Brexit and I believe the EU27 recognises that the UK is essential to intelligence against terrorism, and they should respond quickly and positively.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, women suffer the highest temporality and work less hours in gainful employment. In both the European Union and Spain, 30% can only access part-time contracts; the wage gap is 16% in the European Union and 24% in Spain, my country. This situation of discrimination in the labour market is reflected and aggravated by reaching retirement, where women's pensions are 40 per cent lower than men's pensions. The policies of cuts also bear the seal and signature of patriarchy and a vision of society asymmetrical and fragmented in terms of gender, which condemns us to permanent inequality, subordination and cloistering in private space. But we have the firm conviction to end this system, with the patriarchy inherent in capitalism, and that is why we call for participation in the feminist strike of March 8. We are going to make March 8 a historic day, because if we stop, the world stops, because we want each other alive, we want each other free and united.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President! In its report, the Advisory Committee of the Council of Europe Framework Convention on the Protection of National Minorities revealed a number of unresolved problems regarding the enforcement of the rights of national minorities in Romania. It itemizes the violations and official acts that characterise the everyday life of national minorities, specifically the ongoing anti-Hungarian incitements that come from the Romanian-language media and some politicians. ET's findings are true, and over the past 10 years we have highlighted the problems we have indicated here in this house. The report undoubtedly points to the fact that in Romania the problems of national minorities have not been resolved and the country is far from being considered a standard for the exercise of minority rights. The report of ET must have consequences. It is time for the EU institutional system to put this on the agenda, because it is obvious that an EU Member State is in gross breach of its obligations to protect minorities on accession.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, equality between women and men, the fundamental principle of the European Union, remains a subject of major importance, as women continue to suffer from inequality, face multiple forms of discrimination. Today I would like to draw attention to the role of women in the agricultural sector. Romania ranks first in the European Union in the share of the population working in agriculture and second in terms of the share of women in this field. That is why women farmers are all the more appreciated as they managed to succeed in a men's world. At EU level, only 4.4% of the working population work in agriculture and only 30% of farms are managed by women. Huge sustained efforts are still needed for the development of female entrepreneurship. I call on the European institutions to create more effective legislative levers to ensure that rural women and girls receive support for their entrepreneurial and innovative initiatives, which could provide additional income for their families.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Madam President, the Boka Navy was created more than 12 centuries ago, when Kotor sailors participated in taking over the power of St. Tripoons. It is the cultural and spiritual heritage of the Catholic Church and Croats, the indigenous people of Boka Kotor. Therefore, we were all caught by the news that Montenegro decided to include the Bokela Navy, independently, without Croatia, on UNESCO's list of intangible cultural heritage of mankind, especially since it is registered in the national register of cultural goods of both countries. Croatia seeks a joint nomination, which will evaluate the role of Croats and the importance of St. Tripoons. By denying the fact that the Bokeljska navy is the dominant heritage of Bokela Croats, it is encroaching on the core of minority rights of Croats in Montenegro and is part of a trend that directly accelerates the disappearance of the remaining few Croats in the area of Boka by oppressing their cultural identity. This approach of Montenegro, which is a candidate for membership in the Union, is a gross violation of the rights of the Croatian minority and is contrary to the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: — Madam President, although negotiations on Britain's exit from the European Union are moving forward, there are still signals that the situation of citizens of the Member States in the United Kingdom is not fully clarified. Uncertainties persist, even as a result of agreements reached in recent months. There are over two million European citizens whose fate is now being decided and, of them, at least 200 000 are Romanians. We are talking about people with families who have created a future in the UK, or who are working on building this future. If all post-Brexit issues are not clarified, we risk waking up with a phenomenon of forced exodus from them, with dramatic social and economic consequences. I sound an alarm signal to the European Commission and the European Council, but also to Britain, not to sacrifice the fate of millions in this political process of getting out of the European Union. We are talking about European citizens who have contributed a lot to economic growth, both of the UK and the European Union.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President! The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Raad al-Hussein, has slandered Prime Minister Viktor Orbán with xenophobia and racism. Yesterday, regardless of this, one of my interlocutors classified Hungarians as nationalists. I strongly reject these and similar unfounded accusations. A nationalist who violates rights, but a patriot defends rights. Viktor Orbán defends his own and the nations of Europe, so he is a good patriot and a good European. Politicians advocating the invasion of migrants, on the contrary, act at the expense of their own people and their citizens. Against the intensified anti-Hungarian opposition towards us, we minority Hungarians living abroad are defending our own people, for example in Ukraine, where on 4 February there was a nationalist terrorist attack on the headquarters of our Hungarian community in Uzhhorod. As true patriots, let us act together to defend Europe and our peoples.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: — Madam President, in recent days something has happened in Slovakia that has shook the whole of Europe. Two young people — investigative journalist Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend Martina Kušnírová — were brutally executed in their own home. Ján Kuciak was a brave journalist who wasn't afraid to uncover the cases of organized crime, whose strings extend all the way to socialist politicians. In the latest unfinished article, he even pointed to the link between the Italian mafia and the Direction party at the head of the government. This heinous act is not enough just to condemn. I propose, together with my Czech colleague Luďk Niedermayer, that a new committee against financial crimes and tax fraud should also be addressed to cases of tax fraud on which the murdered Ján Kuciak worked. We best honor the memory of two brave people by contributing to the unraveling of the truth. We always have to do everything to make decent people have the upper hand.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — I would like to talk today about the dispute that may be set against the backdrop of the selection of the President of the European Commission. President Tusk, Juncker and Czech Prime Minister Babiš have spoken on this topic in the past few days. EP promotes the notion of top candidates who should be the ones relevant to proposing to office. For me, sometimes the EP pushes this issue in an irreconcilable way. The European Council enforces its right of nomination, which corresponds to the text of the Treaties in force In my opinion, the Treaty in force should be followed and the sane European Council should propose a candidate who can gain the trust of the EP with his Commission. The role of the Member States should be more fundamental. The President of the European Commission should just be elected on the basis of the choice of Member States. I do think that than graduate to another controversy, it would be better to respect our primary right.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: This item on the agenda is closed.
